The house was never clean enough for her taste. She often hid out in her room. She got mad at them for eating her special food. She was always yelling at and fighting with their dad. Maybe it was true or maybe it was just kids complaining. Darcy and I had long pretended to get along for the boys, but I always felt like she resented me when I did well and celebrated when I did badly. Underneath the pretense was the simple fact that, no matter what, I was always going to be the mother and she was always going to be the stepmother. She could never change that or, perhaps, forgive me for that. After months of dragged-out mediation over custody, my arrest had settled it once and for all. I knew Bryan would take care of Kaden and love him while I was in jail. I knew Kaden would be happy as long as he was around his big brothers. Darcy was a necessary evil, but better than strangers. I sent her as much love and light as I could. I hoped her heart would be open to Kaden. I was grateful to her and wary of her at the same time. Now she holds my baby in this picture, and it feels like she is staring straight into my soul. Now she has all my children all the time. She has won. I push thoughts of Darcy away and try to stay in the moment. Jail is a great place to learn to meditate, and it’s going to be my New Year’s resolution. I sit on my bunk breathing every day of December—first for five minutes, then ten, then thirty, until I can meditate for an hour without feeling like more than five minutes have passed. It’s a way to beat crazy jail time at its own game. After an hour of meditation there’s a feeling that’s almost like getting high. Not quite, but close. I wish I knew how many hours of meditation would equal twenty Vicodin. When people speak to me, I practice being present and sending them love. I do this with the guards, with the judge and prosecutor when my case is continued yet again on Christmas Eve, with Daddy and Nina and Kiki and Vivian. I send love to the scared women who come in for their first time. I also make sure to tell them how everything works in G. I give them the orientation I never got. All day long I send love out to the world. To my children. My neighbors in Aptos. To DJ and Bryan. I even send love to Darcy, but then I think of her clutching Kaden and I take it back. I’m not the Dalai Lama, after all. The other women tell me that I will definitely be going to prison and that I should start working out now so I can try out for fire camp. We go in the courtyard and do sit-ups and push-ups and walk in endless circles. No one can figure out how many times around the small courtyard is a mile. The guesses range from fifty to a thousand. On Christmas morning I wake up and walk around the courtyard for hours. I meditate as I walk. I meditate all day long so I don’t have to think about life outside G block. The time between Christmas and New Year’s is extra boring, so Daddy and I hatch a plan to break up the monotony. Leah, who is pregnant, will fake labor pains. She’s only seven months, so Daddy has determined that this will be too serious for normal medical and as a holiday gift to us, she will get paramedics into the unit for our viewing pleasure and just to break up the monotony. She and Leah come into my cell as they are plotting the details. “I need to know what labor feels like,” says Leah. “You have a million children, coach me.” I have nothing better to do so I agree. “Do you get period cramps?” “Yeah,” says Leah. “It’s nothing like that,” I say. “It’s like this pressure that builds, kind of from the back, and then it wraps around and tightens.” I think back to all my labors with Dylan, Cody, Ty, and Kaden. “It’s like no other pain there is when it comes. A tightness and a squeezing and sometimes the pain is so bad it takes your breath away.” I know this is pretend, but I see in Leah’s face the realization of what awaits her when she has her baby. She looks scared. I am about to say it’s okay because it’s all worth it, and you have this beautiful baby, and you fall in love like you’ve never felt love before, but I stop myself. Her baby will be taken away from her in the hospital. She will give birth handcuffed to a bed. She will fall in love and have her heart broken at the same moment. Everyone is excited to start the New Year with visions of paramedics. Daddy pushes the panic button and calls the guards. “Leah is going into labor. She’s in pain, come quick!” she yells. Leah has taken over an empty bunk on the freeway, so everyone can witness the performance. Two guards rush in and hover over her. “Oohhhh it hurts, it hurts…” she moans. They try to get her up, but she screams louder and says she can’t move. Her performance is high-school-theater level, but it convinces the guards. One talks into his shoulder radio and instructs someone to call 911. It only takes about ten minutes for the paramedics to arrive. Firefighters also. There are four of them, and they are young and gorgeous. The guards lock everyone in the cells, but we watch through the windows as they stand around Leah. Within minutes two more paramedics come in with a gurney. We watch in disbelief as Leah is wheeled out of G. Right before she’s rolled out the door, she flips us all the bird. The guards unlock the cells, and Daddy asks where they are taking her. “Dominican Hospital,” one of the guards says. As soon as he leaves the room, there’s a mad rush to the phones. Three girls call their drug dealers and tell them to get to Dominican Hospital emergency. Leah is on the outside and will be coming back in once they realize she’s not in labor. This wasn’t the plan, and I feel my power in G slip a little. Did Daddy keep this part of the plan from me? It’s no secret that I don’t use the drugs DJ sends me. I don’t know if this was the real plan all along and Daddy says no when I ask. I’m not thrilled at the idea of more drugs in G, but I could never say that. It’s so hard to stay clean in G and I’m almost at sixty days. I’m proud of myself, but when they are around, the cravings are stronger than my meditation. In recovery they always say, “If you don’t want a haircut, then don’t hang out at a barber shop.” There’s no catchy platitude for when you’re locked in the barber shop twenty-four hours a day. Leah doesn’t come back before lockdown, so I go to sleep not knowing if she was met by a cavalcade of drug dealers in the ER. I am awoken by yelling. Patricia and I jump up. I slept in my clothes, but she is in her bra and underwear only. There are about ten guards in G shouting, all the doors are open, and the lights are on. “Everyone out on the floor, now!” they scream. Girls are running down the stairs. Patricia tries to grab her clothes, but the guard yells at her not to touch anything. There’s yelling from Daddy’s room, but I don’t have a chance to turn back before we are all rushed out of G block. Shakedowns have happened before but there’s usually some warning and people have time to hide their second mattress in the shower or tuck any contraband away in hidey-holes around the unit. Not tonight. The entire unit is marched through the jail until we get to the big holding room you pass through before you go to court. There’s a giant wire cage in one corner of the room. It’s square and looks like the temporary fencing that goes up around construction sites. We’re all herded into the cage and stand there stunned as it’s locked from the outside with a giant padlock. I look around at some of the regulars to see if this is normal, and I can tell this is not normal for anyone. I don’t see Leah; she must still be at the hospital. I think about all the calls made to drug dealers. I had heard girls talking about the trick we played on the guards over the phone. After a while it’s easy to forget that the guards are always listening to everything. It is freezing in the cage, and poor Patricia is half-naked and shivering. “Hey,” I yell to one of the guards. “Yeah?” “Can you get her some clothes? She’s freezing.” I nod toward Patricia. “Yeah, sure, no problem.” Thank God for small kindnesses. I give her a big fake smile and say, “Thanks so much! Hey, do you happen to know what time it is?” “Why? You have somewhere to be?” She laughs and walks away. I’m guessing it’s 2 a.m., maybe three. Girls are huddled together on the floor trying to fall back asleep. Daddy and Kiki and Vivian are whispering. I need to see what’s up with them, but first I need to get Patricia dressed. The guard brings her some reds and a big beige coat. “Whoa,” I say, “I’ve never seen one of those before.” “Blaine Street coat,” says Patricia. “So they don’t get cold walking over to the kitchen.” It’s a huge coat, with thick canvas material on the outside and soft flannel inside. It’s warm. It’s luxurious. It’s amazing. We’re left in the cage for hours. Daddy is pissed because she has a lighter in her cell and doesn’t want to get another demerit. The more demerits you get, the less credit you have to shave days or even weeks off your sentence. We sit in there through what would normally be breakfast time, and it’s almost light out when they bring us back right before the shift change at 7 a.m. The guards don’t say a word as they march us back to G. None of us have any idea what they were looking for or what they may have found. G is in shambles. The freeway mattresses are scattered all over the floor, and everything from the cells has been dumped haphazardly along the tier: books, letters, legal papers, blankets, clothes, toothbrushes. Family pictures painstakingly glued on the walls with toothpaste have been ripped down. Shelves engineered from empty maxi pad boxes have been crushed. Commissary items are scattered. It’s like a Category 5 hurricane hit G. This wasn’t an investigation—it was punishment. We’re all trying to sort whose belongings are whose when Leah comes back in with a big smile on her face. I can’t deal with all of this and the temptation of drugs at the same time. I assume that’s what she’s smiling about. I quickly get on the pay phone to call my boys. If anything will strengthen my resolve it will be talking to them. Because DJ always has money on his books I use his S-number whenever I need to make a call. The system will charge his account. I dial his S-number and the operator says it’s not valid. I think I must have done it wrong so I try again. I keep trying. If there wasn’t money, it would say not enough money and to call collect. I have never heard the not-a-valid-number message. This is not possible. I run to my room and pick up one of his letters from the floor and look at the number on the envelope. I don’t have the number wrong. I try to call again as panic sets in. My mind starts to conjure all sorts of disaster scenarios. He’s overdosed and in the morgue. He’s been shanked and is in the morgue. He’s been taken off to prison now even though we haven’t even had a trial or been sentenced. My hands are shaking. I don’t know what to do. I have no money on my books to make a call. I call my mom collect. No answer. I don’t want to call my mother-in-law. I’ve tried to avoid her because I’m pretty sure she hates me and it’s just too much to deal with. I pace nervously around G, not sure what to do after the mess is cleaned up. I keep trying to use his S-number. Maybe the jail found out I was using it for my calls and shut it down. Maybe that’s what the not-valid number means. Maybe this is more punishment. G block is excitedly listening to Leah’s account of the ambulance ride and the real ice cream they gave her in the hospital. No drugs got through because they took her to the maternity ward rather than the ER. “Braxton Hicks,” she yells at me as I stand at the bank of phones. “You forgot to tell me about Braxton Hicks contractions.” I shrug. I’m just glad there are no drugs to tempt me. I gather my courage and make a collect call to my mother-in-law. I wait for it to connect, and I hear her accept the charges. There’s a shuffling and cracking sound as if the phone has been dropped, and then I hear a man’s voice: “Hello?” “Hello?” DJ says again. “Hello?” I whisper. There is a long pause, and I feel as if G block just flipped sideways. I press my hand against the wall to steady myself. “I got bailed out,” he says. “You mean your mom bailed you out…” “Yeah.” He’s trying to keep the glee out of his voice, but I hear it. He is sleeping in a soft bed and eating good food and taking hot showers. He’s been getting high all the time while I fight to stay clean, and he is free. I want to scream. I want to cry. But I swallow it all and try not to choke as it goes down. “Amazing,” I say. “Look, baby, I’m going to get you out of there, I promise. We’ll be together soon.” “When did you get out?” “A few days ago.” “Have you talked to Kaden?” He doesn’t answer right away, and then he’s angry. “I’m not going to call that fucking house!” “Have you not talked to him since we were arrested?” I am shocked. I never asked, but I assumed he was trying to call and talk to him as much as I was. “You didn’t call him on his birthday?” I can hear DJ inhale deeply, and I realize he’s smoking. “Look, I have to go, we’re about to go to lunch.” “Well, I don’t want to keep you from lunching.” “It’s not like that, I need to do what my mom says, you know how it is…” “Okay. Can you at least put some money on my books so I can call the boys?” I realize that he’s been out for a few days and hasn’t done this yet. I know what he’s doing with any money he has. “Of course, and I’m going to get you out. Who always takes care of you? I will sell everything we have.” I doubt we have anything left to sell, but I don’t argue. “Call me tonight,” he says. “Wait,” I say before he hangs up. “You need to call CPS! You can do supervised visits. You can take the parenting class. You can start all the requirements. You need to right away or we’ll lose Kaden!” “Gotta go. I love you, homegirl.” I hang up and head back to my room. I imagine DJ free and me in prison for years. I vow never to call him again. When I get back to my cell, Patricia has everything in order. She still has the coat, and it’s laid across her bed like a comforter. “Look what I found,” she says, a huge smile on her face. She’s holding a small radio. “How the hell did you get that?” “It was on the floor outside the cage. When we left, I scooped it up and hid it in my nice big jacket.” She adjusts the antenna, turns the dial, and gets a local pop station. And when Beyoncé’s “Single Ladies” comes on, Patricia turns the volume all the way up and moves the radio to the doorway. Everyone stops cleaning up the mess and starts to sing. I don’t think about DJ anymore. I don’t think about my boys. Just for tonight, G block is the only family I know. The only family I want to know. I smile and shimmy until lights out. That night Patricia is snoring, and I stare up at the darkness wide awake. I’ve never been able to lie to myself between 2 a.m. and 4 a.m.—those hours have always been when my conscience wakes me up with the truth—since I first stole my aunt’s jeans. I’m too exhausted to use any of my Tolle tricks, so I lie in the dark and let every worry and fear and regret and pain settle in. I press play on my life and watch all my mistakes flicker past my mind’s eye. I see my fake smiles and my posturing and my decades of pretending everything is okay when it isn’t. I see all the lies I have told, all the untruths, all the omissions. I see every bottle of Vicodin I have stolen. I see every credit card I have taken. I see everyone I have hurt—my boys, DJ, Bryan, Darcy, my mom, my neighbors, my friends. I see every ridiculous story I have told to hide my addiction. I see all the moments, years really, where I could have easily asked for help but my ego, my denial, and my shame prevented me. The thought that I was already in jail before I was in jail floats around in my mind, but it’s both too ephemeral and too complicated for me to unpack. I try to look at my life as if it’s a story and trace the plot that has gotten me to this bleak place, but there are too many missing pieces. I want to blame some moment for my addiction, some trauma, some loss. But mostly I want to blame somebody. Someone has to be responsible for who I have become, so I put the people in a lineup and try to pick out the perpetrator. My older sister was killed in a car accident. My brother died of a heroin overdose. My other brother had mental health issues and a gambling problem and often threatened suicide. I never had a father. I never had a mother who was present. I never had a normal family. My first husband cheated on me. My second husband is an addict who just abandoned me in jail. I don’t know the language of grief or loss or emotions at all—it was never spoken in my home. I can’t remember a single time in my life when someone asked me “How are you?” and I answered honestly. I don’t think I have ever known how I am, or who I am. I have always felt like an actor playing the role of me. My whole life I had pretended to be a beautiful, happy, shiny person in the hopes that would somehow make me a beautiful, happy, shiny person. I fit in everywhere because people love beautiful, happy, shiny people. But the problem with me trying to fit in everywhere is that I have never actually felt like I belonged anywhere. Or with anyone. I couldn’t reach out for help before the police came knocking on my door because I was so desperately playing the suburban mom role I’d created. This is how a real mom shows up to school board meetings. This is what a real mom makes for snacks. This is how a real mom should sacrifice herself for her children. I vowed to be the mom I never had, but she and I turned out to be just the same. Absent. Gone. If my children need me tonight they can’t call me. I wonder if showing up as a fake version of yourself is just as bad as not showing up at all? I run this idea around in my mind, poking and prodding at it to see if it holds up. It doesn’t. The truth is, I would have preferred any version of my mom to being alone. So I am actually worse than my mom. I can study the people in my lineup and make them turn right and then left, but every time I try to point my finger at someone or something, I can’t. There is no one to blame but me. 
 chapter 10 ROLL IT UP Our public defenders are trying to work out a plea deal. Elizabeth comes to see me, and she is not happy that DJ is out, but super happy that I am still in. “You’re safer in here,” she says. “Really? It doesn’t seem all that safe.” “If you were to get out and commit a crime, do drugs and get caught, the plea deal doesn’t happen. You will go to prison. I won’t be able to do anything.” “Do you know how many drugs are in this jail? I haven’t done any, and I could have. A lot.” She gives me a weak smile, but I want applause. I need some kind of validation. If I said that in a recovery meeting, I’d get a standing ovation. It’s the one thing I miss about twelve-step programs. They applaud anything as long as you don’t use. You can burn your house down in a fit of rage but as long as you don’t pick up, you’re a hero. “Do you think we’ll get a plea deal?” “I’m trying, but the DA is going at this hard. Probation too. They really, really don’t like you. Your husband also, but they seem overly focused on you.” “But not the actual DA, right? It’s the assistant DA?” “It’s all the same. But it’s the ADA and the head of Probation. They want prison. If you weren’t a white woman, you’d get prison for sure.” I nod because it’s true. Mimi, a Latina in G, just got sentenced to four years for embezzlement: using her company credit card for personal expenses—more or less the same crime that put me in G block. Everything in her case happened ridiculously fast. Arrest, sentencing, and onto the prison bus in less than a month. Mimi has two children she’s raising on her own. She supports her parents and grandparents too. When she left, she said she’d see me in Chowchilla. She assured me that prison is much better than jail—easier. She had family members in prison, she said, so she knew what to expect. You get more visits, you get classes and workshops, you can work and stay busy. “Does the DA look at all the cases?” I ask Elizabeth. “Like does he know about them?” “Of course.” It’s probably not helping my case that I once dated the current district attorney, and by dated I mean had a torrid affair with him while he was living with another woman. It was 1989, and I was in my last year of college and working as a manager at Player’s Pizza—a sports bar and grill around the corner from the courthouse. He would come in after work, alone or with coworkers. He was tall and blond and while he introduced himself as Tom, I immediately renamed him Sven because he looked like a Nordic god. I flirted with him shamelessly, and he began to stay at Player’s until closing time, waiting for me to get off work so we could spend time together. Sometimes he would take me into the courthouse after hours and make love to me in all the offices, even once in what he called the gun room. Gun rooms are sexy, and I don’t even like guns. He would spend hours at my small studio apartment, letting me read through his confidential case files and discussing strategy. He was a new assistant district attorney then, a decade older than me, and I was about to go off to graduate school. When I moved back to Santa Cruz after Dylan was born, we reconnected as friends, and I would sometimes visit him in his offices at the courthouse, where, knowing my writerly curiosity, he would tell me about cases he was working on and let me listen to 911 calls. He had never lost a trial, a fact he was very proud of. He was also bitter about his first marriage ending and shared how hard the divorce was and how upset he was about the claim she had made on his pension. When Tom ran for district attorney in 2002 on a family-values, law-and-order platform, I had to laugh. There were definitely no family values happening in the gun room, but that felt like a lifetime ago. Our friendship petered out as life went on, and now was impossible given that he was technically prosecuting me. It couldn’t help my case that his new wife was high up in the probation department. I didn’t know if she was aware of my history with her husband, but when Elizabeth says that Probation is taking a hard line on my case, I have to consider it a possibility. On one of our early court appearances, I saw him off to the side in a huddle with other attorneys, and I wondered if they were talking about me or one of the dozens of other cases before the court that day. I was too ashamed to meet his eye, and I imagine he wasn’t eager to acknowledge me either. “I’m going to keep at it,” Elizabeth assures me. She puts a hand on her belly again. “How’s your son?” She used to be a CPS attorney before becoming a public defender. “He’s good. He just turned four. I talk to him when I can, but it’s so hard… he doesn’t understand why I’m not with him.” I tear up. “Hang in there,” she says kindly. When I get back the unit is in a tizzy. Rooms are getting switched, and when I ask Daddy what’s going on, she says that they got word Princess was in booking. “Who’s Princess?” Daddy looks at me like I’m crazy. At times like these my position in G feels tenuous. I don’t know the players on the streets. I know there are girls everyone is afraid will come into G, and other girls they wish would come in. Apparently Princess is a big-time meth dealer—the original lady boss—competing in a man’s world and making a killing. Patricia and I are split up, and I move into a room with Kiki. It’s the last room on the top tier. A corner room, so it’s the biggest. Daddy is next door. Patricia moves to the bottom tier. I’m happy to move in with Kiki. She’s smart and funny and tough and sweet. She’s barely older than Dylan so I feel most like Mama Love around her. I’m anxious that Princess’s arrival will mean more drugs in G. It’s almost rude of me not to do drugs that are offered, but I really don’t want to. I’m working on my YA novel and mailing pages to Ty to type up. My mind seems full of creative ideas. I jot down notes for short story ideas. I long for a keyboard. In prison I would have access to a computer. It’s the only upside of prison I can think of. When Princess arrives, Vivian and Daddy rush her upstairs. She doesn’t look like a drug dealer: She’s tiny with long strawberry-blond hair, pale eyes, and freckles on her face and arms. I don’t want to see what she brought in. That night Kiki gets permission from one of the guards—the one who brought in the McDonald’s—to spend the night in Daddy’s room. She asks for a sleepover, and he laughs and says okay. I can hear them through the wall all night long. It’s a meth party for sure. And when the moaning starts, I recall Kiki telling me that when she does meth she just wants to watch porn and fuck. My meditation is no match for the threesome next door, so I just stare into the darkness. I think about my boys asleep just a few miles away and wonder what they are dreaming about. I send them love and light and sweet dreams. I hum their favorite made-up lullaby: “Mommy loves you, yes she does, Mommy loves you just because…” Dylan, Cody, and Ty are too old for lullabies, but I sing it to them anyway. I imagine myself scratching Kaden’s arm so he can fall asleep. I hum all night long until the lights come on for breakfast. Kiki doesn’t eat breakfast. Neither does Daddy, Vivian, or Princess. They divide their meals among the other girls when the guards aren’t looking. If a group of inmates stops eating, it’s a sure sign there’s meth in the unit. The meth bender lasts for three days until the drugs run out. Nobody in the unit sleeps. It’s a G-block rave, and the guards don’t say a word. Everyone but me from the top tier is in a sleepover cell. Eleven girls crammed into two rooms. Kiki is back in my room, and she’s exhausted. She looks like she’s lost ten pounds in three days, but I don’t comment. It’s commissary night and because my mom had put twenty dollars on my books I receive a batch of chocolate and ramen and new sandals. Kiki and I freeze. “Love, roll it up!” I look at Kiki and she looks at me. “What did he say?” I ask in disbelief. “He told you to roll it up,” she whispers. I suddenly feel guilty and afraid. It helps that I’m sitting in my mother-in-law’s Mercedes. I am still skinny from my pre-jail diet of Vicodin and chocolate, but I’m dressed nicely for our appointments so I don’t overly concern the guard. And I haven’t done anything wrong. DJ finally shows up, breathless and hurrying. He doesn’t explain his absence, and I don’t ask. My anxiety is building, and I recall my attorney’s warnings. When we get over the mountain and away from Santa Cruz, he passes the exit to Saratoga. I still don’t say a word. He pulls into an IHOP in a strip mall in San Jose and parks on the outskirts of the lot away from the other cars. He reaches under his seat and pulls out a velvet bag. In it there’s a small metal tin, a lighter, a rubber band, and a clump of black tar heroin about the size of a silver dollar. “I told you I met with some guys from jail while you were in your meeting,” he says. “And then I grabbed this from the hospital.” He reaches into his pocket and pulls out a long, skinny object sealed in paper and plastic. In the dome light I can read the words BIOPSY Needle and STERILE. “It’s huge,” he says, “but it’s all I could find.” I have been driving in a car with drugs in it. I was in the getaway car while he stole from the hospital. I have already violated the terms of my bail agreement. “You’re going to love this,” he says as he pushes up the sleeve of my sweater. I am mute as he melts the heroin into liquid and draws it into the needle. Yes, this is something I swore I would never do. But I don’t have the strength to resist. He ties the band around my arm. I watch as if from a distance as he sticks the needle in my vein. It stings and tugs and burns, and then he pulls back a little on the plunger. I see my own blood folded into the brown liquid, and then before I can even take a breath, he presses the plunger aggressively and empties the needle into my vein. For a moment I feel nothing, and then warmth spreads through me. Excitement. Joy. Energy. Every good feeling flows through me. The shower wasn’t church, this is church. All the day’s pain washes away. A part of me marvels at this new, more efficient way of getting high. No inhaling smoke through a straw for hours. No swallowing twenty pills. I’ve always loved efficiency. I don’t think about the fact that it’s also a more efficient way of killing myself or that this is what killed my own brother. My attorney’s words of warning are forgotten. My brief, fragile sobriety is gone. As the heroin swallows me like a pill, I close my eyes and pretend this is good. I pretend this is love.

When breakfast comes, there’s a guard I haven’t seen before. He’s about my age with short brown hair with a little gray at the temples and a big smile. He’s someone I would talk to if I ran into him at a bookstore or a bar—he’s tall and cute and I’ve always been a sucker for gray temples. I think about everyone who has ever known me seeing this. I used to coach Little League, I was on the school board, I was a real estate agent way back when I first left Bryan—everyone I ever did business with is seeing this. Should we post up on the steps outside?” Kiki seems antsy and I know it’s because of the stuff I brought. When my heroin is finally gone, I go to bed early but wake up a few hours later, shortly after lights out. I am feverish and sick. It feels too quick, but there’s no mistaking this for what it is—I’m detoxing, and it’s coming in hot. I run to the metal toilet and vomit. “Sorry,” I say to Kiki when she wakes up. “Sor…” I can’t get any more words out, and the vomiting goes on for hours—long after there is nothing left to get out. I hang on to the toilet’s cold rim and shiver and shake while Kiki softly snores. In the early morning everything comes out the other end, and I beg Kiki to give me privacy. It’s only 4 a.m., but I can’t be so sick sitting on a toilet with someone in the same small room. “The doors are still locked, where can I go?” Kiki asks grumpily. “I know…” I cry. “I’m sorry.” When the locks pop at breakfast, Kiki runs out of the room. I have never felt so ill. Liquid is pouring out of my nose and eyes. I have never detoxed like this. I know there is Vicodin under my pillow but it won’t help me now. I can’t even swallow water. Kiki checks on me at lunch. I am lying with my cheek against the cold cement at the base of the toilet. I can’t get up, but I tell her I’m fine. I try to tell her again that I am fine, but my mouth can’t form words. I vaguely hear her yelling and I think she is pushing the button, but I am watching from far away, and she is just a tiny, blurry speck on a vast horizon in this small cell. I don’t register the two guards pulling me off the floor and half carrying me down the stairs and out of G. I come to in the medical unit, and the nurse is pissed. They will search the room. I am so, so stupid. I risked my whole family yet again for what—to belong in G? To be a big deal there? “I just have a slow metabolism,” I whisper. He shakes his head in disgust. “You need fluids,” says the nurse. She hands me some Pedialyte. “And there’s an abscess in your arm. It’s infected. You’re going to get antibiotics three times a day until it clears.” I have nothing to say in my defense so I sleep. When I get back to G days later, the worst of my detox is over. It fucking took forever, the motherfuckers.” “Thanks,” I say. I look over at my pillow. “Did you hide the stuff?” Kiki looks down and away. “Yeah.” “What’s wrong?” “Well, I didn’t think you were coming back…” I realize she must have taken the rest of what I brought in and used it or traded it. In the normal world of jail this would be cause for someone to get rolled up and probably a beatdown. “I don’t care,” I say. “I’m done.” Kiki is relieved and instantly solicitous. “Let me make you some hot water bottles. It says Mary Hill. I don’t know a Mary Hill. I open it up and there’s a giant stack of printed pages—at least fifty. The first few pages are a photocopy of the newspaper headline and article. Somebody made sure to reduce the size so it fit on a normal page of paper. After the article and in the dozens of pages after is a printout of what must be the online comments to the article. I start reading them and don’t stop for an hour. Someone writes “her poor boys,” and then I see a comment from what must be Darcy writing back: “the boys are fine.” Others talk about how they used to see me at NA meetings—so much for twelve-step anonymity. I can figure out who a few of the commenters are by their usernames. Others are strangers, though. Hundreds of them. Saying I should be in prison, calling me a sociopath, saying I am the worst kind of person in the world. People who are outraged that I am not going to prison. And then there are the more ominous ones. There are ways to make sure people like that go back once they get out. They will get theirs on the street. I read the comments over and over. And each negative word burrows through my skin and latches onto my bones. The hatred, the vitriol, the threats become a chorus in my head. It sings to me a song of my own badness, and the melody settles in and plays on repeat. Everything I have been before this moment—daughter, sister, student, teacher, wife, neighbor, volunteer, employee, boss, coach, friend, mother, human—is gone. The community has spoken. Everything I have been is now erased. There are so many names for me in these comments. I am a criminal, a thief, an addict, a felon, a plague on society, a sociopath, a liar. The Neighbor from Hell.

There is a class on relapse prevention taught by a woman named Tracy who I instantly love. She’s direct and no-nonsense, and we hit it off immediately. There are even volunteers who will come in and do your hair. There’s a chaplain and religious services. A computer class if you need computer training. Music. Board games. And work. Lots of work. Each day you must clean your room before 7 a.m. Beds have to be made military style. Floors are mopped daily. Bathrooms cleaned. All are subject to inspection at 7 a.m. Once a week, on Sundays, it’s double scrub—in-depth cleaning, closets organized, every surface, knob, and wall scrubbed to perfection. Once the daily chores are done, the girls at Blaine Street go to the main jail to clean and cook for the entire facility—without them the jail would cease to function. I’m assigned to clean the public lobby of the main jail and the sheriff’s offices. I start work at 6 a.m. Only one deputy comes into the main office that early, and we chat it up every day. She calls her mom every morning, and after a couple of weeks she hands me the phone so I can say hello. Her mom always asks if I’m doing okay and staying out of trouble, and I assure her that I am. And I’ve let everyone know at Blaine Street I am not getting involved with anything shady. I know there are probably drugs waiting to be couriered under the tampon bags in the public stalls that I clean, but I don’t look. If anyone asks me to check, I tell them to fuck off. During my mornings emptying trash bags and cleaning bathrooms, I think about how much Blaine Street relies on women’s unpaid labor. If Blaine were empty, the jail would be in trouble. No meals. No cleaning. It’s a system completely disincentivized to rehabilitate people. Their business model doesn’t function without a high recidivism rate. If all the women in County were successful, exhibited good behavior, and became productive members of society, it would break the county budget. The sheriff’s department couldn’t afford hiring actual workers, so local taxes would get raised. People could barely afford the cost of living in Santa Cruz as it was, and proposing higher taxes rarely went well for local politicians regardless of the reason. Recidivism was the only financially viable path forward. The only way for the government to win is for the inmates to lose. It’s as simple as that. There’s an actual library at Blaine Street, and I read every volume. My new favorite is The Book of Awakening by Mark Nepo. It’s organized in daily dated essays, and I read it like a horoscope—looking for whatever wisdom I need to get through this particular day. It’s uncannily accurate. One of his observations resonates especially strongly with me: Pain pushes you until vision pulls you. After lights out, I lay in my bunk bed and try to trace my life back to the moment when I stopped letting a vision for my future pull me and started letting pain push. Because I did have a clear vision at one point. And it didn’t have anything to do with marriage or money or motherhood. From the time I first escaped into books, all I wanted was to be a writer. I was going to write novels that moved people, that helped them understand the world and themselves better. I wanted to make people feel, whether it was laughing or crying. And if the vision also had me rich and famous and fabulous, I was okay with that. Writing was always the only way for me to make sense of my childhood, my family, my fears, my emotions, my vast and confusing interior world. I was always a better version of me on the page. I was always at my most honest on the page. I could transcend every limitation I believed I had when I wrote. In high school I may have lived in a small apartment while my friends had big lawns but writing transcended class. Writing transcended loneliness. Writing transcended self-doubt and fear and heartbreak. I never needed a drink or a drug to write. When I took that first pill after Dylan was born, I stopped writing. I told myself it was having children, and financial troubles, and a difficult marriage that made writing impossible. I told myself there wasn’t enough time in the day to write. But all the excuses were lies. Opiates made writing impossible. The drugs I took to avoid pain kept me from the one thing that helped me cope with pain. Writing was my survival strategy and a bridge to other people. It gave me a sense of self-worth. It gave me joy. But mostly it was how I let feelings flow through me. Once I stopped writing, every bit of pain stayed in my body where it settled and weighed me down so much that the only way I could move through life at all was to take a pill as needed for pain. Then two. Then ten. Then twenty. Then sixty. And every time I tried to stop, tried to choose a life without something to dull the pain, I couldn’t stop for very long. I couldn’t stop long enough to realize what I really needed. I needed the writing. I start writing again. I write stories on the computer and print them out because we aren’t allowed to save documents. I write an essay about anger. There’s a woman in Blaine with the last name Doll who suffered horrible childhood abuse and I write a story about the million ways to break a doll. I read the story to Tracy, after relapse prevention class one night, and she sits in silence when I finish. “Can you please read that to me again?” she asks softly. I read her the story again. And then I read her my essay about anger. “They’re so great,” she says. “I’m blown away. Can I take them to make copies?” Every day that I write, I feel vision pulling me. It’s not a clear vision, but there’s a tug. Writing not only passes the time, it makes me feel like I am me again. The old me. The real me. The me before the mess. Tracy brings back many copies of my anger essay, and it gets passed around Blaine Street. When Jacinda, a thirty-year-old who looks like she’s twelve, comes to me and asks if I can write her letter to the court asking if she can be moved from Blaine to a long-term residential treatment program, I’m not sure if I know enough to argue on her behalf for treatment. We sit on a bench in Blaine’s backyard, and I ask her why she wants to go to an eighteen-month treatment program rather than just do her six months at Blaine. “Because I don’t want to come back here,” she says. “I don’t want to go to treatment, but I need to go to treatment. Look, it’s eighteen months of structure and regular meals and therapy and support, but I’ll be safe there. You feel me?” Drawing on Eckhart Tolle’s advice, I stay as present as I can while Jacinda speaks. She tells me about her ex who always finds her, and her mom who died two years ago, and her sister who has been raising Jacinda’s son for so long that he thinks she’s his mother. I have to put my own desperation to get out of jail aside—I would never trade six months for eighteen months—and really listen to Jacinda. I try to see the world through her eyes, understand her backstory. It’s not pretty—one horrible foster home after another, running away from abuse, getting raped and kidnapped while high, getting locked up for the first time because she was crashing at a drug house that got raided. “Okay,” I say, after she’s shared her stories for over an hour. “I’ll write your letter.” “What do you want?” asks Jacinda. I always forget about the quid pro quo of jail friendship. I’m trying to cut my carbs, so I’m done trading things for bear claws. I fall silent as I ponder what else I could possibly want in this place. “I’ll make your bed every morning,” she says. “Please…” I suck at making my bed. I can never get the corners as smooth and tight as the guards demand. I nod and smile in agreement. “And,” she adds, “if I get released because of your letter, I’ll make sure someone else makes your bed until you get out.” It’s a great incentive, but when I sit down to write the letter to the judge, I’m not thinking about my messy bed. I’m imagining that I am Jacinda and all she’s been through. I’m thinking about how many times I’ve been in and out of jail and how badly I want the structure of the residential program. I write a long letter imploring the judge to send me to treatment, to give me a fighting chance to never come back to jail. As Jacinda I end the letter with this: “I never had anyone care enough about me to tell me when to go to bed, to make sure I was eating healthy, to ask me how my day was. I want to follow the rules. In Santa Cruz Residential, they may not be my family but it will still be the closest thing I’ve ever had to a real home. Please let me go home. It’s all I’ve ever wanted.” Jacinda and I mail the letter, and for the next two weeks she makes my bed every morning before inspection. When the classification officer comes over from the main jail and asks for Jacinda, I go down to the lobby with her. He seems rushed and gives me a slightly annoyed look as I listen in on their conversation. He hands Jacinda a stack of paperwork. “You get transferred tomorrow to treatment,” he says. “Pack it up tonight. They are coming for you at six a.m.” Jacinda bursts into tears. “Okay then,” he says and walks away quickly. Jacinda and I look at each other, stunned. She throws her arms around me. “I’m so happy for you,” I say. “You deserve this, you deserve a real chance.” “Thank you,” she says. “I don’t know how you did it, but what you wrote… it was just everything I’ve ever felt and didn’t know how to say.” I hug her back tightly. There’s a feeling I don’t recognize that immediately overwhelms me and my eyes well up. I’m so happy for Jacinda but it’s something else. I’m proud of myself. And for the first time in a very long time, I feel good. I don’t see Jacinda the morning she leaves, but at 7 a.m. a quiet girl named Eve taps on my door and then walks in and makes my bed in silence. I try to ask Eve about herself, about what Jacinda traded her for, but she just smiles at me and shrugs. Whatever it is, she’s not saying. She comes every single morning before seven. When she’s not making my bed, Eve crochets all day, only breaking for meals. Her room is lined with hundreds of baby-sized caps and booties. The crochet volunteers collect them every month but where they take them is a mystery. I imagine a hospital or maybe the treatment center for pregnant women. After Jacinda, I have a steady job ghostwriting legal letters, love letters, birthday letters, anniversary poems, arguments in family disputes. I even write eulogies for two women who get passes to leave Blaine for funerals. I break up with a few gangsters, and I tell one poor schmuck I need a divorce because I’ve fallen in love with a woman and now have a jail wife. I prepare for each assignment the same way I did with Jacinda—by listening. Sometimes I worry I could get in trouble for pretending to be other people, especially since that’s what put me in jail in the first place. But I’m helping rather than hustling now, so I don’t worry too much about the fallout. I love pretending to be someone who isn’t me. All my years writing fiction help me to be a different character. When I talk to my clients at Blaine I listen for their particular quirks of language and phrasing, the way they tell a story. There are only a few judges in criminal court in Santa Cruz so I’m extra careful to vary the voice in each letter and match the voice to their individual backgrounds, education, and culture. The more letters I write, the easier it becomes to become another person. To think like they think. Reason like they reason. Occasionally I write how someone feels and they freak out because they didn’t tell me that they grew up never trusting other women, or that because they were abandoned by their father they always chose bad men just like him, but it’s true for them. It’s kind of spooky, and the girls whisper that I must be psychic. I don’t discourage their suspicion because it’s fun, it passes the time, and saves me from having to make my own bed. When I occasionally make a prediction about something entirely predictable that comes true, I gaze intently into people’s eyes as I deny that I’m psychic. And I don’t explain that the reason I can write so accurately about their fears, their shame, their desperation to be loved, to be better mothers than they had, or their struggles to stay clean, is because in all these ways we are exactly the same. I don’t yet realize that what I am doing is honing my empathy—the superpower of all great ghostwriters. 
 chapter 13 MOTHER’S DAY I get moved to kitchen duty at Blaine Street, and I get permission to grow a garden in the backyard. Each morning and night I work the soil, plant the seeds, tend to the vegetables that I will eventually cook and serve to my fellow inmates. I have never been a gardener, someone who loved to get her hands in the soil. But it’s different gardening in jail. Planting seeds feels hopeful and even the slow pace of vegetables growing feels exciting because there is something new being tended to and born. Soon after I plant the garden, Amy, Kaden’s CPS social worker, begins making plans to bring him for his first visit. I have called her every day since I got to Blaine. I am determined to do what I can from inside to get my boy back. Every week I ask her what I can do to move my case along. Rather than seeing her as a bureaucrat who wants to take Kaden away from me, I choose to treat her as my ally in getting him back. I choose to believe that the goal of everyone in CPS court is to return Kaden to me rather than take him away permanently. I try to manifest this into being, and I tell myself that the judge, the attorneys, the social workers are all working with me toward this goal. “What more can we do?” I ask them. “What more can I do?” I ask myself. This question becomes my mantra and consumes every waking hour. I slowly become an advocate for myself and for the other women going through similar CPS cases. One of the requirements to reunify within the allotted year is a positive-discipline parenting class. After I’m released, there will be no way I can complete this class within the one-year time frame. I lobby hard on behalf of all of us at Blaine and get an amazing woman, a former mayor of Santa Cruz, to come to Blaine Street and teach the class. Amy agrees to bring Kaden to a court-supervised visit once a week, but only if all the other girls in Blaine Street agree to stay in their rooms during the visit. It’s the only way CPS will allow the visits to count toward our reunification. All the girls agree to stay locked in their rooms. I don’t know if it’s because of the letters I have written for them, or because so many of them have already lost children to the system, and they empathize with me. These women—mothers, sisters, friends—are rooting for Kaden. He is brought in for his first visit. We read books and play badminton. He sits on my lap, and I cuddle him and promise him I will be home soon, that we will be together. I walk him along the side yard so the girls can see his joy, which their sacrifice has made possible. He smiles and waves to them all and blows them sweet four-year-old kisses. I think it gives them hope. Because my new job in Blaine Street is running the kitchen, I can make him a snack like it’s our own kitchen. I make him hard-boiled eggs, which he loves to peel. I squirrel away boxes of Froot Loops so I can pour him a bowl of sweet cereal when he asks for it every week. I still worry that he hasn’t grown an inch since my arrest, so I feed him as much as I can. We work in the garden and talk about how each plant grows bigger just like him. I will him to grow. Each week he tries to leave something with me, a piece of clothing, a toy, his shoes. “I want to live here with you,” he begs. “Please, Mommy.” “I love you, Boo Boo,” I tell him. “I wish you could live here, but it’s not allowed, plus your brothers would miss you.” He clings to my neck when it’s time to go, and I murmur “soon” as I rain kisses across his face until he laughs. I do my best not to show him my breaking heart. After he leaves, I grieve the loss all over again. When he cries to stay with me, I tell him Darcy and Bryan love him and are taking care of him for me. I want him to be happy wherever he is—and I do not say a negative word about Darcy, although he repeats cruel things she has said about me. I will never make him feel like his loyalty is divided or feel guilty for his happy moments away from me. I know I am his mom, and there is no ticking clock, or law, or judge, or social worker who can change that. DJ hasn’t yet made it to Rountree—the medium-security facility for men on the other side of the county. He has had no jailhouse epiphany like mine. If anything, jail is making him worse; he’s affiliating with gang members and doing drugs, and the jail stops allowing letters between us because he’s doodling gang symbols in them. When I ask the social worker what happens if both parents aren’t doing what they’re supposed to, she tells me the judge has the power to view each parent’s requirements separately and give custody back to one parent and not the other. “Of course,” she adds, “if you are living with the other parent and he is using drugs or hasn’t fulfilled his requirements, it would appear like you are not putting the well-being of the child first. Sometimes safety means there is only one parent in the picture.” I nod. Pain pushes and vision pulls. I’m done with pain. Officer Lonnie is the main deputy who works the day shift at Blaine Street. I am amazed that everyone calls her by her first name until I realize Lonnie is actually her last name. She is there from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. most days. Lonnie is about my age, with big brown eyes that can stare at you for an uncomfortable amount of time without blinking. She likes to think she doesn’t miss anything that happens at Blaine, but she does. She wears her dark hair pulled back in a severe bun. The guards don’t ever give out personal information, but from what I can gather, she is second generation from somewhere in Southeast Asia. When I get up at 5 a.m. to start cooking for the thirty residents of Blaine she offers me coffee. Real coffee. Guard coffee. She finds the fact that I’ve never tried pho more offensive than my felonies. She tells me how her various relatives make pho, what they each put in it, the five main spices, and how the pho at the diner nearby compares. She also shares the latest Hollywood gossip with me in hopes I will share the latest Blaine Street gossip with her. One day I ask Lonnie if I can make banana bread as a treat for the women of Blaine. I hand her a list of ingredients I will need. As a working mom, I never had time to bake and garden like I do at Blaine. I always thought of baking and gardening as luxuries of the idle or unambitious, but I was wrong. There is something about growing things and feeding people that makes my soul feel good again. I wish I had gardened and baked more when I had a home of my own. “What do you have to offer?” asks Lonnie. It’s not as creepy a question as it sounds. Lonnie is trying to move up in the corrections department, and the more contraband she can confiscate from inmates the better it is for her career. Confiscating involves a lot of work for her and a lot of stress for the residents of Blaine, so Lonnie and I have worked out a system: I collect contraband for her so that nobody gets in trouble and in exchange she brings in treats. It’s a win-win, no-fuss-no-muss system for everyone. “What do you want?” I counter. “Two lighters,” she says. Lighters are a coup in the guard confiscation world, since they are needed to smoke cigarettes or drugs, and they can also start fires. I come back with an offer of one lighter, and the deal is done. There are lots of lighters at Blaine, so it’s easy to get a volunteer to give one up for the possibility of banana bread. When I ask for two DVDs and cake mix and frosting, we have a harder negotiation. She wants three lighters and a pack of cigarettes. We settle on two lighters and five cigarettes in exchange for a full movie night experience for Blaine Street where we can stay up until midnight. We are drinking our morning coffee when I finally get up the nerve to ask her about going to the Gemma Program—an eight-week reentry program where about ten Blaine Street residents get to leave in street clothes two days a week and take classes at a local church in relapse prevention, nutritious cooking, music, yoga, résumé writing, and life skills like how to balance a checkbook. “I’d like to do it,” I say. “You don’t really need it,” says Lonnie. “Please!” I beg. “It’s not up to me. You have to meet with Cassandra, she’s the program director. She’s coming to do interviews tomorrow for the new session. I just refer people to her that I think can be trusted and who will benefit from it, but it’s her decision.” “Will you refer me?” She says nothing, just smirks at me between sips of her coffee. “What?” I ask. “You don’t think I can be trusted?” I ask this lightly, but my voice shakes a little. It hurts. I want people to trust me again. Lonnie sets her coffee down and laughs. “I already referred you.” Lonnie doesn’t show much emotion, nor is she moved by others’ emotions. But she does have compassion, and I’m grateful to her. Cassandra pulls me out to the lobby to interview me. She’s a large Black woman who exudes joy from her purple-glitter eye shadow to her flower nose ring to her colorful flowing scarves. I’m afraid she’s seen the newspaper headline and read the online comments. I read them constantly, trying to figure out the identity of each username. I know which comment is from Darcy. I know which are from people in recovery. I know which name is an old boss. But the bulk of the comments seem to be from strangers—people who read the article and have a lot to say about who I am and what I’ve done. It’s almost like reading your horoscope every day and trying to see yourself in the description—if your horoscope threatened you and called you a sociopath. Reading them is like poking at a wound that’s trying to heal. They are the opposite of positive affirmations, but I can’t seem to stop. Cassandra and I chat for twenty minutes as she tells me about the program, the classes. She asks me why I want to attend and I don’t bullshit her. “I really want to leave here twice a week,” I say. “I’m not going to lie about that. But I also love school, learning, and homework. I want something to focus on besides cooking and cleaning and waiting for visits from my boys.” “I think you’ll make a great addition to the Gemma Program,” Cassandra tells me. She has the kindest smile I have ever seen, and she beams it at me as if I am worthy of such kindness. “But…” I stammer, “I just want you to know…” She looks at me expectantly, still smiling. I don’t know how to say what I want to say. I feel inarticulate and like I need to make sure she knows what she’s getting into so that she doesn’t regret offering me a place. “There was this headline,” I begin. “I have thirty-two felonies, and I just want to make sure you know… that I’m really, I mean everyone thinks I’m really…” I finally blurt it out. “I’m a bad person!” Cassandra tilts her head and stares me straight in the eye. The kindness and warmth don’t leave her face. What I say doesn’t seem to shock her, but she doesn’t speak for a good thirty seconds. “My son was in the paper once. I’ll tell you about it someday, but meanwhile I’ll be here at seven a.m. on Tuesday to pick you up,” she finally says. I nod and thank her. As I stand up, she hugs me. Lonnie, watching from the guard station, doesn’t stop her. Lara the mom gets hugged and cuddled by Kaden every week. But Lara, the neighbor from hell, has never been hugged like this. I fold into her and rest my head on her broad shoulder. Her perfume is sweet. I want to stay here forever. She murmurs “It’s going to be okay…” over and over, and we stay like that for a few minutes. In Cassandra’s arms, I feel like I am good. The Gemma classes are taught by local volunteers, and the church gives access to the meeting room and the kitchen for free. A few weeks into the session I find out some girls have been stealing money from the collection box at the church. I put a stop to it right away, making them return what they stole and confess to Cassandra. When they protest, I remind them that I control the Blaine Street kitchen, which also means I control the cheese. In relapse prevention someone said that there’s a chemical in cheese that’s identical to one in heroin. I don’t know if that’s true, but I do know that in Blaine whoever controls the cheese controls the women. Halfway through the program, Alice, a volunteer, gives us homework where we have to list all the pros and cons of restorative justice versus punitive justice. Back at Blaine, we all gather in the computer room and talk about what it would be like to sit in a circle with the people we have harmed and hear their experience of our crimes. Some girls say they’d prefer a judge to facing their victims, and I think about sitting with my neighbors and trying to explain why I stole their checkbook and wrote a check at the grocery store. Or why I used their social security number to get credit to buy a Kindle. I don’t know if I could explain it in a way that wouldn’t sound like I wasn’t taking responsibility. “I was out of my mind” doesn’t cut it. “I just wanted to read parenting e-books” makes me sound inane. I didn’t want to hurt them. But my life for the last year was like driving at night in heavy fog; I could only focus on a foot in front of me. I had no peripheral vision for anyone or anything else. I definitely couldn’t see my neighbors. I can’t imagine one person who was in the courtroom when I was sentenced choosing forgiveness over punishment. I don’t think I could make that choice if someone hurt my family, violated my sense of safety and security. Restorative justice was great in theory but we Gemma girls couldn’t imagine forgiving ourselves, much less asking others to forgive us. I am the fastest typist in Blaine, so I help all the girls type up their homework and print it for class. At the next class, Alice and I are sitting across from each other, at two ends of a large conference table. The rest of the girls are on either side. “Did anyone have any problems with typing it up?” she asks. “It’s okay if you had to handwrite it.” “I helped everyone type it on the computer,” I say brightly. The weeks are flying by now, and I’m in great spirits. Tracy, the relapse prevention teacher, had challenged me to stop reading the newspaper comments about me so I have, and it’s lifted my mood considerably. I smile at Alice, but she doesn’t smile back. She says sharply, “I’m not comfortable with you being on any kind of computer at all.” My stomach flips, and I study Alice more closely to see if I know her from anywhere outside Gemma, Little League or Montessori maybe, but she just glares at me with open disdain. Nobody says anything. One of the rules of Gemma is that you never talk about anyone’s crimes. The volunteers are there to help and support us because they believe in reentry and rehabilitation. Like our homework assignment, Gemma itself is based on restorative justice, not punitive. I can’t respond, and my cheeks burn. I keep my eyes on the table for the rest of the class. When the day is over, and we are putting chairs away in the supply closet, I step inside and start to cry. I feel defeated. Ashamed. I silently berate myself for my optimism. If a Gemma volunteer has such vitriol toward me, then I have no chance out in the world. Cassandra pushes her way into the closet. She’s livid. “She had no right to say that to you,” she says angrily. “I’m going to talk to her.” “I can’t come back,” I say. “What’s the point? I’m done.” I have no anger in me like Cassandra does, but then anger has always come out as sadness for me. “You will be back. You’ll be back on Thursday, and you’ll be back every week after until you graduate. I promise you, nothing like that will happen again.” I shrug and tell Cassandra I’ll think about it. When I walk into Blaine, Lonnie takes one look at me and says, “Who died?” I tell her what happened. “So your feelings got hurt,” she says. “Do you like Gemma?” “Yeah… but…” “Then get over it. Show up and hold your head up.” “But…” “Or no more getting out of double-scrub by having your minions do your job.” This makes me laugh. Lonnie always knows more than I give her credit for. “How about some ice cream for the girls? Ice cream always cheers me up. I like vanilla.” “Figures you like vanilla. No deal. You don’t get rewarded for pouting, so suck it up, Love. And finish what you started.” Lonnie’s right. I want to finish Gemma, so I will. Later that night Lonnie calls me to her window and hands me the office phone. It’s Cassandra. “I spoke to her. Apparently she’s friends with your next-door neighbor.” “Oh, great…” “It won’t happen again,” says Cassandra. “Not on my watch. And you don’t have to do her class anymore. And she won’t be coming back next session.” “Thanks,” I say. “I guess I’ll see you Thursday.” “You bet your ass you will.” On Mother’s Day, Bryan brings Dylan, Cody, and Ty to visit. It’s always awkward to see Bryan, and even more awkward when he keeps telling me how good I look. “I mean, you look so healthy,” he adds. It’s true. I exercise every day, I meditate, I go to bed early, I have lots of friends. But mostly I feel hopeful. At first it felt like I would be in jail forever, but now I see an advertisement for a movie coming out in October and I think, I will be out of jail when that movie premieres. The boys and I sit in Blaine’s backyard and talk. I tell them stories about the other girls, silly fights people get in, how we trade lighters for cake mix, and I give them the beanies I have crocheted for them. “I got into Cal Poly,” says Dylan. I scream and hug him. My firstborn is headed for college. “I’m so proud of you,” I say. “When does school start?” “The end of September.” I will be out, I think. I will be out of jail to see him off to college. Cody talks about basketball and his new girlfriend. Ty talks about his friends in junior high and the academic awards he’s winning even though he skips classes whenever he can. “I believe in cutting out the middleman,” he says. I look at him, puzzled. “The teacher.” He laughs. “I don’t need the teacher to learn or to do well on the tests.” The old me would have freaked out on him, told him he can’t skip school and that teachers are important. The new me just listens and understands. Because it’s Mother’s Day there’s no time limit on the visits, and the boys and Bryan stay all day. We play badminton and check out the garden, but mostly we just sit and talk and laugh. “I’ve been writing,” I say. “I’ve missed it so much. I don’t know why I stopped writing.” “Don’t stop, Mom,” they say. “You should do what you love.” Sitting in the shade under a tree outside the jail with my boys should feel weird and painful and awkward. But there’s so much love between us under that tree that I realize I didn’t need all those trappings to prove I was a loving mom. I didn’t need a big house and a big car and private school and fancy vacations. None of that mattered or matters. I realize in this moment that I am a better mom in jail than I have ever been outside jail. Our conversations feel more real, more raw, more honest. We’re not fitting into any preconceived roles—we can’t. I used to think the most important thing was that my boys get into Stanford, or some big Ivy League college like Harvard, but now I realize it’s not that important. Dylan is happy to be going to Cal Poly, so I’m happy. If he’d told me he decided not to go to college, I would have still been happy. Bryan and I aren’t fighting, and every time one of the boys says something funny our eyes meet in shared understanding: We did this. As flawed and fucked-up as we were, we created these beautiful humans. The Love boys have always had each other, but now, thanks to my arrest, they have their mom back. I’m not keeping secrets. We are each expected to give a speech. Friends and family, judges and attorneys and city officials, and even some guards attend the ceremony. I invite my sons, but only Dylan and Cody can make it. In my speech, I talk about the experience of time in jail. I talk about how I used to treat time as a limitless resource, and not the precious and rare commodity it actually is. I see him watching me dance, staring at me intently while I give my speech. He gets up to leave when the reception is about to begin, and I track his movements to the door. He turns around at the doorway and our eyes meet. He smiles. I smile. In this small moment we are friends again. We are on the same side. It’s a long summer without Gemma to break up the monotony, but I work in the garden, and Lonnie lets me do landscaping in the evenings in front of Blaine Street. I am always working during shift change at 7 p.m., so the main jail guards all see me out front with no locked doors between me and the outside world. Some have started to wave to me every evening, others just frown and look concerned. I love these evenings of freedom—pruning rosebushes, pulling weeds. Plants never judge you.
