I think of all the times I took my boys there—riding the baby rides on the boardwalk until they were big enough to go on the Giant Dipper roller coaster. Kaden would still be on the baby rides, and I imagine us eating cotton candy and playing carnival games together. On nights when the summer fog rolls in, it makes me moody and nostalgic for everything I have lost. I don’t want to cook dinner for thirty women; I want to cook dinner for my family. I don’t want to mop jail floors; I want to mop a floor in my own house. I don’t want to prune the jail’s rosebushes; I want to plant my own garden in my own backyard. Each night I go to sleep thinking I am one day closer to all these things. And each morning I wake up not knowing how the hell I’m going to make any of that happen. At the end of June Michael Jackson dies. Lonnie and I discuss his demise over coffee. It’s got to be opiates, I tell her. I’m pretty sure he was an opiate addict. Lonnie disagrees, and we fall into a heated debate. In July, reports emerge about his history of abusing pain medication. Even though she runs a jail filled with women who suffer from substance abuse disorders, Lonnie still doesn’t understand how someone who has everything can throw it all away. Such behavior doesn’t fit her no-nonsense, deal-with-it mentality, so I try to explain how the drugs just take over. How they make nothing else matter. “But you know what you’re doing,” she says. “You still know right from wrong.” “Of course,” I say. “Then if you know you are doing the wrong things,” she says, giving me a pointed look, “then you should know enough to stop.” “It just doesn’t work that way,” I say. “Well then you ask for help…” I think about all the times I could have asked for help and didn’t. In my mind, there was no way I could ever be away from my children for the thirty days it took to go to rehab. It feels ironic now that I’ve been away from them for nine months. “There’s so much stigma and shame,” I say. “For me, it would have meant admitting that I didn’t have my shit together. I was afraid of being judged. Seems like a small price to pay now. I was super invested in pretending like everything was fine, and I was the perfect mom. Perfect moms don’t go to rehab.” “So how’d that work out for you?” Lonnie asks. “And you still knew right from wrong when you were out there committing all those felonies.” I think about it for a minute. “It wasn’t that I forgot right from wrong,” I say. “Drugs don’t do that, at least not for me. But they did make me forget who I was, if that makes sense. I didn’t forget the law, I forgot myself.” “What does that mean?” “It means I forgot that I’m someone who would give you everything I have before I’d ever steal from you. It means I forgot that I’m someone who’s happy and fun and likes people. I forgot that I’m creative and loving and careful and thoughtful and generous.” “You didn’t seem to forget that you’re full of yourself.” Lonnie laughs. “But I did,” I say. “I completely forgot to be full of myself. But mostly I forgot I’m someone who wants to live.” Lonnie clears her throat. “Are you going to cry?” I ask. Lonnie scoffs. “You wish.” In August, the jail announces plans for an early-release program to help with overcrowding. They are going to release some inmates ahead of their official out date, but you have to come back to the jail every day from eight to four and work. There’s lots of excitement about this program, but it only reminds me yet again how much the county depends on women’s unpaid labor. Soon after this plan is floated, Lonnie calls me over the loudspeaker on a Friday before shift change. “What’s up?” I say. “I was just looking up your husband’s record on the computer. He was caught with street clothes under his mattress.” “What?” DJ and I haven’t been able to write each other in months, and since we’re done with court dates, I never see him. Or think about him. I declared my love for him in my letters, but I didn’t really feel anything for him anymore. I didn’t hate him; I didn’t love him. And I didn’t know what to do about it. Lonnie reads through the reports on DJ. “Wow, he’s had a lot of trouble in jail. I shouldn’t be sharing this with you, but I want you to know—you guys seem like you’re on different trajectories.” I don’t know what to say to this, so I just shrug. I don’t know if this is Lonnie my friend advising me about my future, or Lonnie my jailer scouting for information. “You should get rid of this guy, that’s all I’m saying.” “Well, it’s not like we’re dating right now.” I laugh, but Lonnie is stone-faced. “You qualify for early release with the new program. You are out on Monday morning.” I am surprised. I thought I had another three weeks. I have no idea where I’m going to live or how I’m going to get to the jail to work each day. The jail doesn’t care about these challenges, and for now neither do I. With freedom so close, it’s hard to think about how hard homelessness will be. “I’m not working this weekend, so this is goodbye,” she says. Lonnie and I look at each other. I can’t tell her that I’ll miss her because that’s just awkward given our circumstances. But I appreciate her, and I will miss her friendship. “I don’t want to see you again,” she says. “I promise I will never be back here. I will never go to jail again. No offense.” “Do you know how many times I’ve been told that, and then two months later I see the person right back here again?” “A million times?” “Probably more. I think you might have a chance—but you need to get rid of the guy. Everyone here thinks so. And if you come back, I will not let you have your own room. I will bunk you up with the most obnoxious person in here.” “Deal,” I reply. “But what do you mean by ‘everyone’ thinks so?” Lonnie laughs. “You don’t think the guards talk as much about you guys as you do about us?” When shift change happens, I am outside tending to the roses. Lonnie drives past and yells out her window, “Try some pho!” I give her a little wave and go back to deadheading the rosebushes so that the tender new buds have room to grow. I don’t tell anyone I’m leaving on Monday. The few days before someone’s out date are always precarious. Sometimes girls sabotage themselves and get into trouble that requires them to stay, and other times another inmate sabotages them. Like any place where thirty women are living on top of each other, each dealing with their own trauma, their own sobriety, their own regret—it can be all kumbaya and girl power until it isn’t. I have nightmares all weekend before my release—where I’m running because I’m being chased, or I’m trying to save my children and I can’t. I know that I’m walking out of Blaine a different person than I was when I walked in—but I don’t know exactly who I am now. I have been so many different versions of myself that I don’t know which is real. All of them? None of them? On Sunday night, right before lights out, I tell everyone I am leaving in the morning, and we have a spontaneous dance party in our quad. Janelle and Mandi help me fold the blanket I have made in crochet class over the last few months. I want to give it to Dylan to take to Cal Poly when he leaves in September. I’ve missed almost his whole senior year of high school. His football games and SATs and prom and graduation. I have missed my oldest son’s most important year of school, and the guilt is all-consuming. In my fantasy life I imagine being back in a home with all my boys, but I realize that because Dylan is going off to college he will probably never live with me again. This realization that some things are just lost to me forever is like jumping into icy waters. It takes my breath away. I shake off the cold reality and focus on my last night with my Blaine Street family. The blanket that I have been blindly crocheting during my months at Blaine has grown to be at least twenty feet long and ten feet wide, and the folding party devolves into dark hilarity. “At least you’ll have something to keep you warm when you’re homeless.” “You could cut it up and have an entire crocheted wardrobe.” “You can hide under it when Probation comes knocking.” At one point, all thirty of us try to fit under the blanket like it’s a fort. It’s all fun and games until Janelle pees her pants from laughing so hard. I go to bed that night smiling, hopeful, sure that the hard part is out of the way. I have done my time. On August 17, 2009, I walk out of Blaine Street forever. When I leave Blaine, I must go immediately to the probation department to let them know my address and get the terms of my release. I have no address, only a prepaid room in a seedy motel called the Hitching Post not far from the jail, where I will spend the next few weeks. An uncle I haven’t seen or heard from in years has offered to pay for this, my mom tells me. I am grateful, but also hurt that no relative of mine ever wrote or visited me in jail. I know that part of my sentence is attending drug court once I’m released, but I don’t know when or how this starts. Drug court is usually an alternative to jail that involves night classes twice a week, random drug testing, immediate incarceration for a weekend if there’s a failed drug test, and the promise of a clean record upon completion of the program. Drug testing is also part of probation, and part of the CPS reunification requirements. Every day I must call three different numbers and see if any of them requires me to get a drug test. I will have three hours to get the test from the time I am alerted. Meeting all the CPS requirements is a condition of my criminal case plea deal; meeting my drug court requirements is a condition of the CPS case; and doing whatever Probation wants trumps all. The various parts of the system are precariously stacked like a Jenga tower. Make one wrong move and it all comes toppling down. I will walk out of Blaine with no car, no phone, no friends, and no idea how to navigate the confusing and conflicting requirements of three different parts of the same system. It feels like a setup because failure at anything means I’m back in jail on a probation violation. The early-release program also means I report to the jail every morning at eight to do yardwork and landscaping. When I leave Blaine, my mom is waiting outside and takes me to breakfast. She has made the hour-and-a-half drive from her home in San Francisco, and I hope that she will stay longer, but after breakfast she drops me off at the probation department and leaves. I give the woman at the front desk my name, and she looks at me blankly. “I just got out of jail,” I say. “They told me to come here and report in or get oriented or something. I have to do it within seventy-two hours, but I’m here today.” The woman has me wait in the lobby for over two hours and then finally the probation officer on duty comes out. “You’re here too soon,” he says. “We don’t have any paperwork from the jail yet. Come back in a few days.” “But I’m on the new work-release program and I have to be at the jail working from eight to four starting tomorrow. You guys aren’t open before eight or after four.” “What’s your name again?” I tell him and then he has me follow him back to his desk. He gets on his computer. “You just got out?” “A few hours ago,” I say. “Yeah, we’ve already had a call about a probation violation. You need to appear in criminal court, Department Three, at eight tomorrow morning. And drug court is at three on Fridays.” “What did I do? What probation violation?” I am shocked. “I’m not your probation officer, you’ll get assigned one once we get your paperwork. But you need to be in court tomorrow morning.” “I have to be working at the jail at eight,” I say. “I just got out. I haven’t done anything wrong.” He just shrugs. “How,” I ask him, “am I supposed to be in both places at once? What do I do? And drug court is at three but I’m supposed to do work release until four.” “Not our problem,” he says. “But if you don’t show up in court that’s another probation violation.” I walk outside and sit on the front steps of the building. My body starts to shake, and I’m hyperventilating. The busy street in front of me narrows in my vision like I’m looking at it through a telescope. I watch the people passing by in their cars—running errands, going to work, getting lunch, driving their kids to and from activities. I bury my face in my hands and cry. I imagine throwing myself into the street, not to die, just to get injured, so a hospital will take me in, and nurses will take care of me. I think about all the girls in the main jail who were released one day and then booked back in the next day for stealing, or fighting, or trespassing, or public drunkenness. One mother and daughter who were in G and then Blaine at the same time used to joke that it was the best home they ever had together. Only they weren’t joking. I always questioned how they could be so stupid to land back in jail so soon, and now I know. Alone on the outside makes together on the inside feel safer. I sit there for an hour, and then I wipe my eyes and make a plan. First, back to the jail to tell them I have to be in court in the morning, then I will walk to my public defender’s office. I don’t know if she’s done with her maternity leave or even still my attorney now that I’m out, but she’s the only one who might take my side and tell me what I should do. DJ won’t be released for a few weeks at least, and I know that if I can survive until then, my mother-in-law will help us find somewhere to live. Maybe lend us a car. I just have to take the first step. And then another. And then another. My attorney isn’t in, but the receptionist tells me that Elizabeth will meet me at court in the morning and to get there fifteen minutes early so we can talk. “Do you know what it’s about?” I ask. “Do you know who called?” “I have no idea, sorry.” That night I triple-lock myself into my room at the Hitching Post. Every surface is both greasy and dusty. No double-scrub here, I think. I only have the forty dollars that my mom put on my books so the jail would give me some cash when I was released, and I don’t know how long that has to last. I don’t have clothes for court. I don’t know what I could already be in trouble for. How can I violate probation before I’m even signed up for it? I consciously try to stay awake because I don’t want to have nightmares in this strange place. Twenty-four hours ago, I was laughing and hopeful. Now I feel like prey.

By all measures, the grant is a success, but, for reasons I cannot guess, the state doesn’t renew it. During my work for CAB, I see that my struggles are hardly mine alone. The barriers to becoming productive members of society are huge for just about anybody who’s been incarcerated. As a condition of probation or parole you have to have a job; to get a job you have to check that box that says you have a criminal record, which excludes you from getting a job. In order to show up to work every day you need somewhere to live; to find somewhere to live, you must have a job. The system is cobbled together out of catch-22s. I learn that if you’ve been incarcerated, you’re ten times more likely to be homeless, and if you’re homeless, you’re eleven times more likely to become incarcerated. It’s a crazy loop-the-loop that’s somehow overlooked in all the conversations about how to reduce recidivism. The system is illogical in its design, broken in its execution, and guaranteed to fail those it allegedly serves. When the grant ends, my job ends. I’m back where I started, which is nowhere. Until Cynthia comes to my rescue again. She calls me shortly after the grant runs out and tells me Cassandra is leaving her position as program director of Gemma. “I want you to apply for the job,” she says. “Are you crazy?” “No, you’re perfect for it. You know the program, you know the needs of the women in jail, you’ve been advocating for incarcerated women, and you have experience developing curriculum from teaching in graduate school.” When she puts it that way, I consider it. “What do I need to do?” “First, you formally apply. And then there will be a series of interviews with me, with CAB, with the sheriff’s office and the probation department. All of them contribute to funding the Gemma Program. I love working with you, you’re amazing, and this is perfect.” The pay is twenty-two dollars an hour, which feels like a fortune. I know I will have to find childcare two mornings a week so Kaden can be brought to school while I pick up the women from Blaine Street in the Gemma van and take them to the church. It’s an obstacle, but I’ll figure that out after I get the job. My résumé is impressive if you ignore the felonies, and I’ve finally found a job that ignores them. I make it through three rounds of interviews. My final interview is with the deputy whose office I used to clean—whose mother I used to talk to. She’s in charge of the jail now, and she is a tough interrogator, but I can tell by the smile and hug she gives me at the end that I nailed it. Before Cynthia calls to officially offer me the job, I’ve already made lists of potential volunteers and classes that will help the women deal with life after incarceration. I know these women and what they need, because I know what I didn’t know and what I needed. I imagine this being my new career—advocate, changemaker, champion of the underdogs. I think back to the sunny winter day when I sat in Elizabeth’s office newly out on bail and heard about the plea deal. Then I still believed, like the twelve million other people who were arrested that year and the two million who were behind bars, that paying for your crimes meant doing your time and following Probation’s orders, and then your debt was paid. I had no idea how wrong I was, and I wanted to do my part to change that. I’ve told everyone about my new job—my mom, the boys, my probation officer. Cynthia calls me on a Monday to tell me my business cards have arrived, and I can start in a week. On Friday morning, I’m just about to go to a twelve-step meeting when Cynthia calls again. “Hello, boss lady,” I answer. “Hi,” she says. “Where are you?” “I’m just about to go into a meeting.” “I have bad news,” she says. “I’m so sorry.” My stomach flips. “What is it?” I sit down under a tree. “You can’t have the job.” “What? Why?” “It came from Probation. They said there is no way someone on probation is going to be allowed to take women out of Blaine and supervise them.” “But Probation was part of the interview process,” I say. “This doesn’t make sense. Probation was aware of this every step of the way.” Cynthia is quiet for a while. “It’s coming from higher up. There’s nothing I can do.” Tom, my old boyfriend, is still the district attorney. His wife is still high up in Probation. I ask if it was her. “I don’t know who it was. All I know is we can’t hire you for the job.” “You can,” I beg. “You’re the head of the program. How can they tell you who to hire?” “They can’t,” Cynthia says. “But they said Probation would pull their funding if we hired you. Without that money, there’s no Gemma Program.” “I understand,” I say. “I feel so bad,” says Cynthia. “I’m so, so sorry. And I’m furious, it’s so unfair, it’s…” I know this isn’t her fault, but I can’t hear any more about the unfairness of the system I’m in from people who aren’t. “I have to get to my meeting,” I say, interrupting her. “I have to go.” “Okay, but…” I hang up and walk back to my car. I don’t have the energy to go to a meeting and hear some old guy in recovery say that “some days you are the bug, and some days you are the windshield,” or hear platitudes like “your worst day sober is still better than your best day using.” It’s just not true. Because sometimes your worst day sober is your worst day ever and getting high seems like a really great day. But what do I know… today I am just a bug. I find an online job at a company called Content Divas where I write blog posts on different topics. There was no background check, just a writing assignment. I have to produce 1,600 words a day. First, it’s ten different posts about savings accounts, then travel in Hawaii. The pay is only enough for gas and rice, but it’s something while I look for a full-time gig. The writing is fun, and I like having a deadline each day and the creative challenge of finding yet another metaphor to highlight the benefits of an online savings account. I imagine walking trails on Diamond Head in Waikiki and write as if I am there, smelling the plumeria and gardenia and being transformed in such a profound way that readers are driven to book their tickets through Content Divas’ client. I’m all too aware of the irony that both a savings account and travel to Hawaii are far out of reach for me. The reality is that I am out of a job, out of money, and out of options. The car I got from my mom’s friend now leaks oil faster than I can afford to replace it, and it can’t accelerate uphill. Today I have an appointment at the county welfare office to appeal the rejection of my application for cash benefits because of my criminal record. I’ve avoided Craigslist when looking for a job because I don’t want to get scammed or murdered, but I realize it’s the only chance of reaching employers without being disqualified by the criminal background question. I decide that if I’m asked, I will reveal my background, but if not I won’t volunteer the information. It’s a don’t ask, don’t tell policy that I feel still jibes with my rigorous honesty policy. I find an ad that’s ten days old, which is a lifetime in Craigslist years, but I call anyway. The woman who answers tells me they are about to make a decision, so I should send an email immediately. It’s an extensive ad for a part-time job as an assistant at a literary agency, but it seems like a fun writing exercise and a way to practice answering honestly without ratting myself out. I think about how great it would be to work with books—my first addiction. Along with my résumé, I’m supposed to write a paragraph about how I exemplify each required quality: organized, integrity, problem-solving, communicator, investigative, computer savvy, flexible, good with money, committed, and educated. I quickly google the company and Doug Abrams to make sure he’s not a serial killer, while at the same time doubting that someone who works with Archbishop Desmond Tutu is actually advertising on Craigslist. I say a quick prayer and pull up a blank screen to write a letter to go with my résumé. I write about how good I am under pressure, at meeting deadlines, at multitasking. How there is no task too small or too unimportant for me to do, and that I’m willing to work hard. I share my education and my writing experience. The integrity topic stumps me for a while, but I define integrity as keeping my word and showing up to do what I’ve committed to doing. I don’t want to lie about my criminal background, but nowhere in the application does it ask me about my past. I read it over and am happy with my responses. I allude to mistakes I’ve made without saying what they are. Don’t ask. Don’t tell. That has to be good enough for now, so I send the email. Hours later, when I read it all over, I realize that I’ve misspelled my own email address on my résumé. So much for that job. Five days later I have an appointment to apply for food stamps. Kaden is with me, and I spend hours trying to entertain him in a dismal lobby crammed with hard plastic chairs and miserable people. We build Legos together while I rehearse in my head exactly how I will plead my case. How can they look at his cute face and then tell me that he doesn’t deserve food because his mom once had a drug conviction? Punish me but don’t punish my son. My phone rings. I startle and drop the Legos. I quickly silence it and look around the waiting room apologetically. I may be a criminal, but I’m not rude, so I answer with a whisper. “Hello?” The woman on the other end tells me she is Michelle, Doug Abrams’s assistant, and he would like to meet with me for the job at Idea Architects, the literary agency. Can I be there in an hour? If I walk out of here now, I’m not sure when or if I will get another appointment to appeal my case. And even if I could interview in an hour, I would need to find childcare, change my clothes, print out my résumé, and get gas. If the office is up a hill, I’m not even sure my car could make it. I can’t go. I hold the phone and watch Kaden walk over to the window and stare out. He needs a mom who is brave, who will feed him and protect him and love him. I don’t feel brave, but… “Hello?” says the woman on the phone. “Are you still there?” “Thank you,” I say, with a loud exhale as I hurriedly pack up Kaden’s toys. “I will be there in an hour, of course. I’m looking forward to meeting you and Mr. Abrams.” Idea Architects is a room attached to Doug Abrams’s house. And it’s up a steep hill. But I get there on time. During the interview we discuss my résumé—my experience teaching English composition and creative writing at UC Irvine, the small literary press I worked for while I was in college—and nothing more. On my résumé I only listed “relevant work history” so Doug doesn’t ask me about anything I don’t want to share. I don’t list the pet cemetery business so I don’t have to talk about losing it because of our drug use and jail. At the end of the interview he also doesn’t ask, “By any chance, do you have an extensive criminal background?” and I don’t volunteer the information. What he does say is, “I’d like to try you out on some tasks first, that way we can both see if we’re a good fit.” “I love tasks,” I say eagerly. “And I’d like to have you edit something for me, and read a manuscript and tell me what you think. I’ll pay you of course for these assignments.” I agree to all of it and spend the next two weeks researching minivans and HEPA filters for him as part of my task list, and when he asks me to edit a biography of Desmond Tutu on a Saturday, I quickly learn how to use track changes in Word and return twelve chapters to him by Sunday. I read another manuscript he sent me—a memoir of a doctor who was diagnosed with esophageal cancer and had some crazy woo-woo experiences but was living in gratitude and joy even in the face of death. I love this guy. I love his story. He makes me want to be someone who lives in gratitude and joy. The manuscript is a mess, though. Kaden and I are driving home from a twelve-step meeting when my phone rings. It’s Doug. “What did you think of the manuscript?” he asks. It’s after 9 p.m. “I liked it, but it was pretty hard to follow the story,” I say, not wanting to offend him. “It jumps around too much to track. As a reader I was lost.” “How would you fix it?” I pull over so I can take my phone off speaker. Kaden is falling asleep in his car seat, and Doug is a loud talker. “Well,” I stall. I do have an idea, but I don’t want to sound ridiculous. I am one hundred percent sure I have a solution to the structural problem, but I have trouble saying it out loud. Sometimes, one hundred percent isn’t enough. I’m not an editor. It’s been a decade or more since I’ve been a writer. I look at Kaden in the rearview mirror, and I think one hundred percent will have to do. I take a deep breath. “I would frame the whole book within the day of his diagnosis,” I say. “But before he tells his family, and then the next chapter goes back to when he met his wife.” I lay out the rest of the chronology quickly. “Hold on,” says Doug. “I’m going to patch you in with the author so you can tell him your ideas.” “Wait, what?” I ask, but Doug has already put me on hold. I haven’t talked to any authors since my MFA days, and they were my professors. I’ve certainly never talked to an author with an agent before, and my heart starts hammering. I jump out of the car and stand in front of it so I can see Kaden through the window. I need to sound serious and professional for my surprise conference call. My previous conference call was an illegal three-way hookup in jail where I had a girl patch in Dylan’s cell phone so I could wish him a happy eighteenth birthday. Impostor syndrome kicks into overdrive as I stammer out my approach to the author, but he loves it. He says it’s brilliant. Doug tells him I will be working closely with him on the chapters and the proposal, and collaboratively writing it with him. I don’t know what collaborative writing means. After we all hang up, Doug calls me right back. “That was great,” he says. “So does this mean I have the job?” “You have the job. Congratulations!” I thank him and do a little dance in front of the car, and Kaden starts laughing from his car seat. I get back in the driver’s seat and buckle up. “We did it, baby guy! We got the job!” He smiles at me, half-asleep. That night as I carry him asleep into our little apartment, it feels like a home. I tuck him into bed in his clothes and kiss his forehead gently. I sit out on the back porch and look up at the stars and thank the universe. The job is only part-time, but it’s a real job. I can work while Kaden is in school. I can help create books that matter, and I feel like I might matter again. For the first time in a very long time peace settles upon me. On my first day at the office, Michelle, who has worked with Doug for five years, greets me. She tells me the Wi-Fi, hands me the keys to Doug’s house and a green pouch with a type of address book in it, and says here are all the passwords to everything and all the bank account and credit card numbers for the business and Doug’s personal accounts. And then she leaves. For a minute I think I must be getting punked, and I stare after her as she drives away. I look around anxiously as if Probation is going to pop out at me. I am alone in Doug’s house with all his credit card numbers. No algorithm needed. I shake my head at such naive trust at the same time as I vow never to break it. Apart from the editing and writing, I’m going to be paying all the bills for the business and for Doug personally, scheduling meetings, coordinating with the bookkeeper, and doing the day-to-day business of running the agency. I don’t know exactly what this entails because my predecessor only gave me a thirty-minute orientation before she peaced out for good. I open my computer and set up a company email address for myself. Michelle had told me that Doug wanted to send out a newsletter with the MyEmma program so that’s what I should work on first. I have no idea what MyEmma is, but I find it online and then I look for the password in the address book and log in as Doug. I quickly learn the program and create a newsletter campaign. The hours in the Craigslist ad said five to twenty a week, but because I want to do more than is expected I bring work home with me every night and don’t tell Doug I’m working unpaid hours after Kaden goes to sleep. We quickly settle into a rhythm in the office and the five to twenty hours becomes twenty-five paid hours right away. At twenty dollars an hour this feels like a fortune. I work on the doctor’s book proposal—a document that’s an abbreviated overview of the book that Doug will use to sell the book before it’s written—on the weekends on my own. I don’t have a desk, so I sit in a big comfy chair across from Doug and work with my computer on my lap. I listen to Doug’s calls with authors, with editors, with friends. He’s smart and generous and curious about everything. He’s enthusiastic and brilliant and full of book ideas. He has three children and a doctor wife, and they are all kind and loving. I sit in my chair watching out the window as his beautiful family passes by in the ebb and flow of their lives, and it makes me both happy and sad. Doug’s son is the same age as Ty, and I love the sound of him and his friends coming and going. I love their laughter, their thumping, their mess, and their energy. Doug and I bounce ideas off each other easily, and he asks my opinion about everything—covers, potential authors, book topic ideas, edits we are each making. It’s like we have been working together for years. We are still in the awkward getting-to-know-you stage, and while at first I was a little suspicious of his kindness, I quickly see that he is just a really good guy. When he tells me I am brilliant, I drive home that afternoon in my leaky, sputtering car feeling brilliant. He doesn’t know that on the day he says this it is my two-year sobriety birthday, but it still feels auspicious. My mind is clear. My energy for the job isn’t chemically induced. Five days later I’m still relishing my natural high and working away in my chair while Doug is on the phone with an author. I suddenly feel the air change, like when a hurricane or a tornado is about to hit, and the world goes silent, and the atmosphere gets thick and muggy and electric. I take a quick breath and slowly look up from my computer and meet Doug’s eyes. In them, I see shock and horror. He ends his call suddenly, his face pale. He stammers as he says, “Gary was just telling me that employers now google all their employees, so I googled you.” For a second I can’t breathe. “I didn’t check your references,” he says slowly. I don’t know what to say or do. I want to run. I want to cry. I want to defend myself, but I can’t. “It says you were convicted of identity theft. That you are the neighbor from…” He doesn’t finish the headline because even in his shock, he is kind. My face feels hot, and the room spins. “I have two years clean,” I say. “I made mistakes… I hurt people… but that’s not who I am when I’m clean.” I want to tell him that because he trusted me so instantly and blindly, I would never betray that trust. I want to tell him that I’m trying to get my children and my self-esteem back, and this work is my opportunity to do that, and I would never do anything to jeopardize it. I want to tell him that I don’t even drive a mile over the speed limit because I will never break another law as long as I live. I will never do anything that will hurt my children again. I want to say all of this, but my throat is dry, and I don’t want to start crying. “Why don’t you leave now,” Doug says. “I need to think about this and call your references and talk to my family.” I walk across the room and pick up the zippered bank pouch. I hand it to him along with the keys to the office. “Come back tomorrow at eleven, and we’ll talk,” he adds. “Okay,” I say. “I’m sorry, Doug. I’m really sorry.” “We’ll talk tomorrow.” I am embarrassed and mortified and ashamed and lost. Fucking Google. I call Cynthia as soon as I get home and tell her what’s happened. “He’s already called me,” she says. “I told him that you managed a million-dollar grant and had access to all our information, and I would trust you without reservation.” “Thank you,” I say. “How did he seem?” “Kind of stressed, to be honest, and a little mad at himself for not checking references before he hired you.” “Would you have told him I went to jail?” “Not unless he asked,” she says. “I can’t go back there,” I say. “I can’t drive back to that house and face him and lose my dream job all over again.” “You can, and you will,” says Cynthia. “You have so much to offer, remember that. I think he’s a good guy. I think he’s going to do the right thing.” At about 4 a.m. I get up and sit on the porch until the sky gets light. The idea of seeing Doug again fills me with dread, but the idea of hiding from him gives me a worse feeling—regret. If he fires me, then he fires me. For a brief shining moment I was brilliant, and I can be brilliant again. He is at his desk when I walk in and sit in my chair. Before he can say anything, I take a deep breath and start talking. “I’m sorry I put you in this position, Doug,” I say, “I really am, but I want to say that I’m just as brilliant today as you thought I was before you read that article. And it’s important to me that you know I didn’t lie to you. If you had asked me, I would have told you. But let’s face it, if I had told you before you asked, I would never have gotten this job. But I am sorry you had to find out the way you did.” My voice quivers, but I speak firmly. “I appreciate you saying that.” Doug’s voice is somber. “I did call all your references. I talked to my family. And I spent all morning really thinking about what it means to walk your talk.” I nod. “Look, I can’t work with Archbishop Tutu and not put into practice his ideas around forgiveness, redemption, and Ubuntu. So what I want to say is I believe in you.” “You do?” “Yes, and I want you to work here. Work with me. Idea Architects needs you.” Tears flow freely down my face. Doug hands me a tissue. “But maybe we hire someone else to handle the finances, and you handle the writing and editing?” “Fair enough,” I say. It stings a little, but I understand. We hire a woman to handle the bills, but I end up overseeing it all anyway. Eventually Doug hands me back the green pouch, the woman leaves, and we don’t talk any more about it. Five months into my job at Idea Architects, we find fraud on one of the credit card accounts—a $700 purchase for a gift basket that nobody ordered. We close the account, and the bank reverses the charge, and Doug seems not to be overly bothered by it since no money is lost. I can’t let the incident go, though. I google the name of the business on the credit card statement and call the number. I talk a store worker into telling me where they shipped the wine basket after he says he cannot legally give me the name. I Google-search all over Ohio until I find all the names that match that address. Unfortunately, it’s an apartment building so there are lots of names connected to the address. I call the store worker back and try again to get the name on the order. He still won’t give it to me. “How about I just say some names to you, and you tell me if any of them sound familiar to you. That’s not telling me anything. Please,” I say, “my job depends on it.” It’s not quite true, but it feels true to me. I start reading down a list of names and he clears his throat after one man’s name. “Does that name sound familiar to you?” I ask. “It definitely sounds like a name I have seen before,” he says. “I would tell you I love you, but that would be weird, so thank you!” I reverse address search until I find the phone number, a landline that matches the name and address. Easy-peasy. I haven’t thought this all the way through, and as the phone rings in Ohio I realize I don’t know what I’m going to say. A man answers after about five rings. “Hi,” I say. “Did you order a gift basket in April?” The man hangs up. I call back and I’m surprised when he answers again. “Look,” I say, “don’t hang up. I’m not the police.” “What, then?” “I just need to know how you got the credit card number you used for the gift basket.” He’s silent for a long time and then, for some crazy reason, decides to answer me. “A guy I don’t know gave it to me, said it might be a working number.” “Did this guy live in California?” “I don’t know him.” I know he’s lying. I also know that sometimes people who work in restaurants will take a quick photo of your credit card when they’re processing your bill and then send the number to friends in another state. This makes the crime untraceable to the restaurant worker, and because people usually eat in the same zip code they live in, the fraudster has everything they need to use or sell a working credit card. “Look,” I say, “the police are onto the scam. And because it’s across state lines the FBI are involved too.” I’m just making stuff up now, and I have no idea what scam I’m even talking about. “You will not get another credit card number from any guys you know or don’t know, okay? You aren’t going to jail this time, but you could next time. And trust me, you don’t want to go to jail.” He hangs up. The next day I tell Doug I tracked down the name and number of the person who used his credit card for the wine basket. “We should tell the credit card company,” he says. I call the company, but they just tell me to call the police. I don’t call the police, though. I hope I scared the guy straight with my crazy phone call. I don’t want to be blamed for the fraud, but I also don’t want this guy arrested. He’ll end up paying for that gift basket for who knows how many years, and I don’t wish that on anyone. I tackled this gift-basket case like I was the love child of the CIA and the NSA, and I go to sleep feeling better. Not because I cracked the case, but because I am now using my powers for good. 
 chapter 17 THE FOUR-MINUTE MILE Work becomes my new addiction. I have taken over the finances and the personal assisting, and, after we rewrite the book proposal and sample chapters, the doctor’s memoir sells for far more than anyone had imagined. I become the agency’s official in-house collaborative writer. When Doug tells me about another writing project he has for me, I reply, “You are crazy.” “No,” he says, “I’m not. You are the perfect person to help write this book.” He’s talking about The Book of Forgiving by Archbishop Desmond Tutu. I don’t know the first thing about forgiveness. I know about forgetting, but nobody is publishing The Book of Forgetting. I am on probation. I am going through a divorce. I am hated by my community. I am the last person to help write a book about forgiveness. DJ is on a path of self-destruction and missed Kaden’s last birthday—just didn’t show up for his party. I have no forgiveness in me right now. I want revenge, but revenge is reserved for people who aren’t on probation. Plus, I have never cowritten a whole book before. The doctor had done a lot of his own writing, and I wrote bits here and there and reworded some of his prose. An entire book feels like too big an endeavor. In my MFA program I only had the patience for writing short stories, and those were short short stories. I have no idea where to begin. “Let’s make an outline of Arch’s philosophy of forgiveness,” Doug says. “A blueprint that you can write from.” He might as well be asking me to speak Mandarin. I’m a fiction writer by training, and I’ve never done outlines or blueprints. Some do, of course, but I’ve never been able to comprehend how you can know the structure of something before you begin writing. I go along with the program, and we loosely sketch out each chapter, questions we need to ask Archbishop Tutu and his daughter Mpho about what forgiveness is and is not. Doug has worked with him before, and they’ve been talking about this book since before I came to work here, so he has a clear idea what each chapter will be about. My job will be to put it all in beautiful writing once we get the content from the archbishop and Mpho, pull content from his speeches, and find the stories to illustrate the big ideas and each of the key points. The whole outline fits on one sheet of paper. On the back side, we list the four steps to forgiving that are going to form the structure of the book. These have been predetermined. “There’s just one more chapter to figure out,” says Doug. The whole process has taken less than an hour. “What’s the last chapter?” “The chapter on self-forgiveness.” I make a face at him. “What?” he asks, when I sit back in my chair. “I don’t know anything about that,” I say. “Of course you do.” I watch him sketch out six key points for the chapter, and then he hands the outline of the whole book to me. “You can do this,” he says. “All your experience in jail makes you the absolute best person to cowrite this book.” I think about Daddy and Kiki and Officer Lonnie and Cassandra. Doug doesn’t know any of my jail experiences, so it’s a stretch for him to say that jail made me the best person to help write this book. But I know he’s trying to hype me up, and I appreciate it. We schedule Skype calls with Archbishop Tutu and Mpho. Because of the time difference the calls are late at night. After Kaden goes to bed, I perch my laptop on my tiny kitchen table and try to angle the camera really high so the yellow fridge four feet behind me doesn’t show. I take notes while Archbishop Tutu speaks, even though it’s all being recorded for transcription. We talk through the outline and revise in real time. I can’t believe Archbishop Tutu is actually in my tiny apartment talking to me. In seventh grade I had done a social studies report on apartheid for my favorite teacher, Mr. Miller. He encouraged me to write every day. I would sit in his class, hiding behind my Farrah Fawcett bangs, and then go home and write stories about all the history lessons he had taught. I wrote a story where I was a soldier in the Vietnam War who didn’t want to fight. I wrote a story that took place during the Armenian genocide. But when we learned about Archbishop Tutu and apartheid, I had written a full essay and created a presentation with poster board and then given an impassioned speech that I was pretty sure would create fairness and equality in South Africa. Now I’m on a video conference with the man himself, but I try to play it cool. Archbishop Tutu is kind and loving and wise and funny, and I pay close attention to his quirks of phrasing and his generosity of language. He is a formal speaker whose language is both precise and lofty. I’ve agreed to do the book, mostly because I don’t really have a choice, this is the job. But then I procrastinate. I don’t call it procrastinating, though; I call it deprioritizing the writing part of the book. It’s not due to the publisher for a year, so I tuck the outline away for as long as possible and instead write more questions for Archbishop Tutu to answer over Skype, and I research forgiveness stories, and I transcribe other talks and do lots of research into the science of forgiveness. When I finally start writing, the early chapters come together easily because I have so much material to work from, but the deadline for delivery is looming, and it’s time to tackle the chapter on self-forgiveness and that’s basically all new material for the book. I pull out the chapter outline and read it over again and then I tell Doug I’m going to a coffee shop to write. I feel important at my big table doing important work, but the blank screen in front of me is terrifying. I give myself an inner pep talk and glance at the clock. I decide I will not leave this coffee shop until the full chapter is written. I start doing calculations in my head. Twenty-five to thirty pages for the chapter, twelve hours until the coffee shop closes, two to three pages an hour, a page every twenty minutes. It all seems reasonable. I think of Doug’s words: There is no such thing as writer’s block—if you are stuck, it just means you don’t have enough information. I turn it into a game. I write all day and into the night about how you have to be willing to face the harm you’ve caused someone, be willing to make amends, and accept that a person may choose to end the relationship even if they choose to forgive you. I look around the room. “That was my nickname, and I’m a graduate of the Gemma Program.” This gets their attention. “I work for a literary agency now, and I’m working on a project called The Book of Forgiving with Archbishop Desmond Tutu and Mpho Tutu. Not yet ready to see that there is humanity in my tormentor’s eyes Or that the one who hurt me may also have cried I am not yet ready for the journey. I am not yet interested in the path I am at the prayer before the prayer of forgiveness Grant me the will to want to forgive. Grant it to me not yet but soon Can I even form the words? Forgive me? Dare I even look? Do I dare to see the hurt I have caused: I can glimpse all the shattered pieces of that fragile thing That soul trying to rise on the broken wings of hope But only out of the corner of my eye. I am afraid of it. And if I am afraid to see How can I not be afraid to say: Forgive me? Is there a place where we can meet? You and me The place in the middle where we straddle the lines Where you are right and I am right too. And both of us are wrong and wronged Can we meet there? And look for the place where the path begins The path that ends when we forgive. Several of the women start to cry, and the moment feels bigger than this little room. After a few moments of silence, I break the tension. “So that one’s a keeper then?” I get the women journals, and for one hour a week for the next six weeks we meet and do the forgiveness exercises. The women are thrilled to be part of a book project, and I understand their thrill. It’s the thrill of feeling like you matter. Like you are part of something bigger than your own sad story. The exercises on asking for forgiveness are hard, as is the discussion about how you have to tell the truth about what you did and then hear the truth about the harm you caused others. But the topic of self-forgiveness is the hardest, especially within a punitive system. The women are hard on themselves, guilty and ashamed and frustrated at the choices they’ve made in life, and I advise them to forgive themselves so they can move on. I tell them that Archbishop Tutu says that telling the truth, witnessing the harm you’ve caused, and asking for forgiveness, even if it’s not given, is the path to freedom. It’s the only way to not be bitter. To not hate yourself so you can have a fighting chance to be something beyond the worst things you’ve done. I teach what I’m not brave enough to do myself. Even out of the system, it’s hard not to stew in the juices of punishment and feel like it’s where I belong. When the book goes to print, I read the acknowledgments section and see Archbishop Tutu has paid tribute to me as his literary companion through many drafts and he calls me an aptly named genius with a heart of gold. It feels good to see my name in his book, to show it to my boys. Chapter by chapter, book by book, I am creating a new legacy to pass on to my children. I am the neighbor from hell in the newspaper, but I am also the person in the acknowledgments of the books I help create. I am officially a ghostwriter, and finishing any chapter feels like being high, only different. The edges are full of confidence, and that makes it nothing like the high of opiates, which were only outlined in glittery fear and false bravado. This feeling will return every time I finish writing a chapter for the next eight years—a feeling I will chase like I used to chase drugs. My phone rings late one night. When I see Darcy’s name on the caller ID, I quickly slip out of bed and go into the bathroom so I don’t wake Kaden. I answer the phone with a question. “Are the boys okay?” “What? Hi.” “Are the boys okay?” I don’t know why she’s calling me so late, so of course I am assuming bad news. “Yeah, they’re fine.” “Okay, good.” I fall silent, and she does too. Over time, we have established a truce of sorts. We took a picture together when Cody graduated high school. We all went to dinner together the night before Dylan went off to study abroad in South Korea. It was easy to fall back into casual friendliness with Bryan; he doesn’t have the attention span to hold a grudge. I am still wary of Darcy, though, and whenever we’re all together, I end up feeling bad about myself. I told them about my job at Idea Architects in a voice I didn’t like. I sounded hungry for their approval, and they looked at me in a way that made me feel like I was lying. I try to focus on the fact that Bryan and Darcy saved Kaden from foster care with strangers while I was in jail. But I still can’t forget all the ways she hurt me when I was hurting. Darcy takes a deep breath, and I steel myself for another false accusation of some sort. I hate conflict, and especially late-night conflict. I am working on five books at once, and I need what little sleep I can get. “I had therapy today,” she says. I remain silent as I sit down on the edge of the tub and play with the snorkel and goggles Kaden likes to wear in the bath. “My therapist says you and I should hang out more.” “What?” Darcy starts to cry. “You’re the only one I can trust in Santa Cruz,” she says. “Bryan is cheating on me.” This news does not surprise me. The fact that I am the only one she can trust shocks me. “I’m so sorry,” I say. I don’t tell her that I suspected as much when I saw Bryan constantly texting during one of Cody’s basketball games. There was a certain look of excitement mixed with chagrin that is Bryan’s cheating face. “But you have lots of friends,” I say. “Why does your therapist think I’m the only one you can trust?” “Because you’ve been through this before, you know what I’m going through, you’re the only one who can understand. Besides, my friends here are his friends too.” Darcy is from Boston, so all her real friends are far away. I don’t know what to advise her. “It’s hard,” I say, “but you’ll be okay.” This makes her cry harder. I am in no position to be the therapist for my ex-husband’s soon-to-be-ex-wife who I think may have tried to get me sent to prison. “I can’t get out of bed,” she says. “I’m so depressed.” I tune out while she sets forth the gory details of Bryan’s affair. It’s not my business, and I’m no scientist, but I bet the research shows that when you marry a cheater, there’s a good chance he’s going to cheat on you. As a woman, I feel for her. As a person once married to her husband, I feel for her. A petty part of me clutches a bit of schadenfreude, but I set that aside. “Try to sleep,” I say. “I’ll call you this weekend.” The next day I talk to Ty, who tells me she won’t get out of bed. On Sunday, I call her. It’s Mother’s Day, which is a tough day for her anyway because she couldn’t bear children of her own. She doesn’t answer. I call Ty again; he says his dad is out, and Darcy is still in bed. I pack up Kaden and we make the short drive over to their house. I park Kaden with Ty, walk upstairs to her bedroom, and knock. A weak voice says, “Come in.” She is sitting up in bed. Her eyes are red-rimmed and swollen. I quickly take in a pile of pill bottles and crumpled tissues on the nightstand. She looks like shit. “How are you?” I ask. “I brought you something.” I hold out a coffee cup to her. “It’s a mocha.” “Thanks,” she says. “Happy Mother’s Day.” She starts to cry again, and I sit on the bed next to her with my own coffee. “Look, I know it seems like the world is ending, but you can’t just stay in bed. Ty said you’ve been in here for a couple of days.” “I can’t get up,” she says. She sounds groggy, and I try to read the labels on her pill bottles without being obvious about it. “It’s a beautiful day,” I say. “Let’s go for a walk on the beach.” She looks at me blankly, and I’m surprised at my suggestion as well. I was just going to hand her a coffee and then slip out. But she’s a mess. I was a mess too. Like recognizes like. “Come on,” I say, “it’ll be fun. It’s beautiful outside.” It’s actually kind of cold and foggy but now is not the time for the truth. I stand up from the bed and hold out my hand. “Let’s go,” I say. “Let’s just go for a walk. I had to bribe him with the promise of Legos to get him to come with me. Darcy reaches for my hand. I want to feel the compassion I’m faking, and when she stands up and stumbles a little, I suddenly do. I don’t want to be a woman who kicks another woman when she’s down. I want to be better than she was to me so she can be better than she was to me. Kaden doesn’t want to walk with us, so we make our way to the beach alone. Darcy stops every few houses to tell me a Bryan story from when they first met, when they once took a walk here, when they were once in love. I just listen and hold space for the betrayal she’s feeling. Bryan isn’t a bad guy, and a part of me is surprised he lasted this long with the bitterness that’s simmered between them for years, but I still support her as she complains about the unfairness of it all and repeats everything she already told me over the phone. We have just turned around to head back to the house. She’s vented all there is to vent for now, so we walk in silence, and it’s actually pretty nice. I haven’t walked with a friend on the beach in years. “I met someone,” I offer. I’m still wary of trusting her with personal information, but I want to build a bridge, and this is good gossip. “What? Who? Tell me everything!” “His name is Sam. He’s great, but he’s seven years younger than me, so I don’t know…” “Bryan is seven years younger than me…” she says and then falls silent. We both know how that’s turning out. “I hope he’s a nice guy,” says Darcy before she starts crying again. “I hope he is too,” I say as I put my arm around her shoulders. Sam does seem like a nice guy; he drops coffee at my doorstep every morning on his way to work. He has two children from a previous marriage whom he dotes on. Since DJ, I’ve tried dating two other men. The first lied to me about being almost divorced; in fact, he wasn’t even separated. The other also turned out to be a liar, and when I broke it off with him, he threatened to call Probation on me. Both were men I met in recovery meetings who were supposed to be practicing the principles of honesty. I had sworn off dating and relationships forever, but then I saw Sam and he saw me. And I liked the person I was in his eyes. I liked that he seemed to love and adore me, but it was still new, and I hadn’t yet told him much about the life I was struggling to leave behind. I told the boys to make Darcy breakfast before we left. When we return, we both climb into her bed, and the boys carry in our breakfast on matching wooden trays. I think about the boys coming to visit me at Blaine on Mother’s Day. At the time, I was so happy to spend the day with them, I hadn’t realized that my time with them meant Darcy had spent the day alone. But here we were years later, spending Mother’s Day together with all four boys. Sometimes, the path of forgiveness doesn’t look anything like we think it will. Sometimes it looks a lot like runny scrambled eggs and overly buttered sourdough toast. After breakfast, the boys take the trays away and I get up to leave. “You going to be okay?” I ask. Darcy nods. “You know,” she says, “I never told you or anyone this, but I’ve had my own struggles…” I think about her anger, her vitriol, her seeming delight at my failure. I think about her leading the mob in the courtroom, and it suddenly all makes sense. Maybe she hated me for all the complicated reasons we hate people who are more like us than we can admit. Or maybe she never hated me at all. Sam comes over later that evening, after Kaden is asleep. His kids are with their mom, and when I open the door he is standing there in his work boots holding a bouquet of flowers and a bunch of carrots. I tell him about my day with Darcy. And then I tell him about my Mother’s Day in jail with the boys, my arrest, my time in jail, the newspaper headline, and Doug googling me. He doesn’t say a word until I’m done. “Thanks for telling me all that. I’m sorry you went through it, but I think you’re amazing. Your past doesn’t matter to me.” “Why?” “I only care about who you are now. And I can promise you one thing, I will never google you. I don’t need to.” How could I not fall in love with a man who refused to google me? A few weeks later, Darcy, Bryan, and I stand awkwardly together for pictures at Ty’s high school graduation. At the dinner that night, Darcy gets drunk, and the tension between them overshadows the celebration. I yell at her for making the night about her rather than Ty, and then I immediately apologize. That dinner is the last time I see Darcy before she and Bryan officially separate and she moves back to Boston. I send her love and light and wish her well. I don’t know what next year’s Mother’s Day will bring. I know I will gladly share my Mother’s Day with the women in jail, with Darcy in her bed, and with whoever comes after her as stepmother to my children. I forgive Darcy and I hope she forgives me.

It’s hard to find a place to rent that has enough room to fit all the kids, takes a dog, and doesn’t require a criminal background check.  chapter 20 MANY LIVES Doug spends the next year writing The Book of Joy based on the dialogues in Dharamsala, and I work on a relationship book about the eight conversations you should have before you marry someone. I never had any of these conversations before any of my marriages. I am also writing a book called Designing Your Life that publishes on the same day as The Book of Joy. Both books hit the New York Times bestseller list. I am ecstatic and proud, and all the hard work and sleepless nights feel worth it. Each literary accolade is like money in the bank to me. A savings account I use as leverage against other parts of my life that are not as successful. I am still on probation even though it should have ended two years ago. To get me off probation, Elizabeth and I go back to court. She argues with Probation, saying that I had gone above and beyond during my incarceration and on probation and I should be let off and allowed to pay my restitution as I can over time without the threat of going back to jail hanging over my head. She tells the judge that Designing Your Life is number one on the New York Times list. I think she is trying to show I have a valid job and also prove I’m a valuable member of society now and will not walk away from my debt. The judge does not seem that impressed. I hate sitting on the bench outside the courtroom waiting for the judge’s ruling. I feel automatically guilty. I can taste jail in my mouth—rusted metal and locked doors and the bitterness of isolation. Before I was locked up, freedom used to feel like a vague, blurry concept and a given privilege, about as easy to pin down as wind. Now I understand freedom in the way you can only understand something when it’s gone. Even out of jail, as long as I’m on probation, I’m still not free. The judge gives me the choice to either stay on probation until restitution is completely paid or make my restitution payments to a county collection agency and get off probation. The judge wants to make sure I understand that the latter option will ruin my credit. Elizabeth starts to argue, but the judge stops her. She looks at me and shrugs. There’s just no way they are going to let me off probation without some penalty hanging over me. The choice is roughly equivalent to declaring bankruptcy, and it will keep my credit rating abysmally low for seven years. Choosing between two bad choices is never easy, but I choose door number two. Bad credit seems better than living while holding your breath. Probation has turned my one-year sentence into a seven-year sentence, and now I have to add another seven years of bad credit. But I take this trade-off in order to sleep in peace. The irony is that probation was originally invented as an alternative to incarceration. In the mid-1800s a man in Boston convinced a judge to let him keep another drunken man in his care so he could rehabilitate him before sentencing. When the State of New York introduced probation in the early 1900s, one of the magistrate’s arguments for creating a probation system was that it could be “punishment without disgrace, and effective without producing embitterment, resentment or demoralization.” Disgrace, embitterment, resentment, and demoralization is just another Monday in the modern world of probation. And if it was hard for me to navigate all the conflicting requirements and illogical bureaucracy as a white, educated woman with some social support, how difficult was it for others without the same sort of opportunities and privilege? Late at night I sometimes read through the jail arrest logs, so I know when Kiki is back in, and the same for Spider, Vivian, and Nina. The only women I don’t see rearrested are the ones who went off to prison. I send care packages to them through the commissary—chocolate bars and bear claws and ramen. I know the money should go to paying back my own restitution, but this is a different kind of restitution. These strangers saved my life and lifted me up with their friendship when I was at my lowest. I owe them. Meeting the Dalai Lama and Archbishop Tutu and all the other authors I get to interact with every day makes me feel valuable, but so did these women. The difference is, I could be honest with these women. Living a covert life, whether for good or bad, takes its toll. If I am only as sick as my secrets, well then, I am in hospice. And I have had enough. Not enough to tell my secrets, but enough that I have decided I need to move away from this place I have lived for the last twenty-five years. I’m going to work my ass off and save enough money to pay my restitution and move far away. I want to go live in Hawaii, on an island thousands of miles away from this community where I no longer belong. I tell Doug this stretch goal. “I need to save up enough money—Kaden graduates in 2023 and then when he goes off to college I’m going to move to Hawaii. I can work remotely.” “Is that what you really want to do?” “Yes. I want to build a big family compound for all my boys—a place where they can come home to, a place where if they have families one day they can bring them. And when I die it will be theirs to share and create memories in. “I’m tired of running away from things,” I say. “I want to run toward something. And that something is Hawaii.” “So, if I’m understanding you correctly, you want to run to Hawaii?” I laugh. “Yes, exactly. Someday I’m going to run all the way to Hawaii.” “If that’s what you want, then I support you in doing that, and you have job security for life. I choke on my scrambled eggs and take a sip of water. The number one rule of fight club is I don’t tell our authors about my past. Doug is to my right at the small table in a hotel restaurant in Montgomery, Alabama, across from the offices of the Equal Justice Initiative. Bryan Stevenson, one of the country’s leading social justice activists and lawyers, and one of the authors we represent, sits across the table, and we’re catching up and having a nice breakfast before meeting Anthony Ray Hinton for the first time. I want desperately to be his cowriter. I take a deep breath. Montgomery’s air is humid, thick with its history of slavery and oppression and the fight for civil rights. I know the sound of a door closing that you have no power to open yourself. I know about being judged. I know Ray before I’ve even met him, and I know that of all the books I’ve worked on, this is the book I was meant to do. He shows compassion and kindness and understanding and says how relieved he will be to have someone working with Ray who has knowledge of the criminal justice system. Ray, whose mother died while he was on death row, comforts me long distance in my grief. When I say I don’t have the words for grief, for regret, and I worry whether I did the right thing in her last days, he tells me to write about it. “I did,” I say. “I wrote a little each night for the last week of her life.” “Read it to me,” he says. Ray insists it will help me feel better, so I read him what I have written of the past week. Bryan and Ray know about my past, so I bravely tell another author I work with before I work with her, and she doesn’t run away from me screaming. For my birthday, I decide to try something I’ve always wanted to do but was too terrified to try: improv. It’s been so long since I played, since I acted silly, since I lived in the moment without carefully scripting all my interactions with others. This tribe of misfits and theater geeks and artists and writers welcomes me warmly. They invite me out to lunch after class. And so every Saturday morning, I put aside work and fear and hypervigilance, and I stand on a stage saying ridiculous things and laughing for two hours. I have found my tribe, my people, and not one of them knows about my past. When improv becomes the gateway drug to a stand-up comedy class, my new tribe comes to watch me perform my routine. Alone on a small stage I say, “So this one time when I was in prison…” and I do a routine about my felonies and how someone gets a prison nickname and how a woman made a tiny candy shiv out of a Jolly Rancher. Afterward my new friends come up to me and say, “Is that true? Were you in prison with thirty-two felonies?” Because I have learned to be in the moment from improv class, I reply immediately in the time-honored improv style. “Yes, and… it was jail, not prison.” There is silence at first, but before I can even get mortified, my new friend Eileen says, “Cool.” The others follow with similar responses, and we all go to lunch where I am not the center of conversation. And my definition of freedom gets bigger. I thought what I craved was approval and praise, but it’s simpler than that. I craved acceptance. For all the different versions of me I have been, and all the many lives I have lived. I am riding the comedy wave with my tribe, and it’s such smooth sailing that when a local Rotary Club asks me to come speak to them about my work, I readily say yes. They don’t mention my past, and I am excited to talk about our literary agency and the impact our books are having in the world. Our team has grown so much that with our foreign rights coagents, staff, and the collaborative writers I have hired and trained, we number close to thirty staff now. Ty is working full time for our company as well, and Cody is creating videos for us, so my success is also their success. The work is nonstop, and I go to the office on a Saturday morning. I am getting a contract out of Doug’s inbox when I see the email. It’s from: one@victimoflaralove.com. I open the email and read: SHAME ON YOU FOR PUTTING THIS VILE PERSON IN CHARGE OF FINANCIAL THINGS. THE COURT HAD BANNED HER FROM BEING IN THAT KIND OF FUNCTION AND YOU ARE BOTH VIOLATING THAT. I WILL BE CONTACTING THE D.A. AND COURTS. The sender has included a link to the Sentinel article—I guess in case Doug didn’t know about my past. The panic attack hits me right away. I can’t control my breathing, and my office seems to have tilted. I want to run but I can’t feel my limbs. All I can think is I’m going back to jail, and so is Doug. I call him, and when he answers I am hysterical and incomprehensible. “Someone sent you… in your email… trouble… jail…” “Take a breath,” says Doug. “Are you hurt? Are the kids okay? Sam?” “Yes, but someone sent an anonymous email.” “Where are you?” asks Doug. I can’t control my crying, and I can hear the fear in his voice, but it’s like I’m listening from underwater. Everything is muffled and removed. “Of… fff… ice,” I stammer. “Stay right there,” he says. “I’m on my way.” I sit on the couch under shelves of all the books we’ve created and realize none of it matters. None of it changes a thing. Doug charges into the office like he’s going to battle, and I start crying all over again. “I’m sorry,” I say. “I’m so sorry.” “There’s nothing to be sorry for. You’re not going to jail. I’m not going to jail.” I hear what he’s saying, and I know he’s being logical, but all I can think of is that my worst fear has come true: My reputation has ruined his reputation. Doug, who has never broken a law in his life, done a drug, been anything but kind and good, is now being threatened with jail. “Let’s go for a walk,” he says. I blindly follow him out of the office, and we walk away from the downtown area of Santa Cruz. I don’t feel safe outside. I don’t feel safe inside. As we walk, I keep looking over my shoulder, sure that the police are going to pull up any moment and take us both away. When Doug stops in front of the bank where we do business, I follow him inside without question. If he wants to get a little banking done while I’m having a meltdown, who am I to judge? We approach Gustavo, who handles our accounts, and Doug greets him warmly. “Listen,” he says. “I want to add Lara as a signer on all our business accounts.” Gustavo looks at me and I know I look like hell, but I smile weakly. This is Doug’s way of showing me how much he trusts me. “I meant to do this a long time ago,” he says. “I just never found a moment where we were both free at the same time. Today is the perfect day.” The paperwork appears in front of me and I sign. Back at the office, Doug makes sure I am okay before he leaves. “This is nothing to be worried about,” he says. “The person who sent that email is a coward. If someone was concerned, they could just call me.” I nod. I know he’s right, and I’m a bit embarrassed that I thought we would both go to jail. When he leaves, I call Eileen. Besides being my new best friend, she used to work for the NSA. I tell her about the email, and she goes to work trying to trace it with some computer magic. The closest she gets is an address. I look it up online, and it is a business park with multiple offices. I leave the office and drive to the address. If someone is threatening me, I want to know who it is. I slowly drive by each business in the lot. A sign shop, an accounting office, a boat supply company. I google each business trying to find out the owner’s name. Is it one of my old neighbors? I don’t recognize any of the businesses. I don’t know any of their owners or employees. I try to think about what could have triggered this email seven years into my job at Idea Architects, nine years after my arrest. And then it hits me. I agreed to give a public talk about my work as a ghostwriter. I search out the Rotary Club that invited me and see that they have just announced me as a speaker. For years I have lived under the radar, and then I forgot. The person who sent this email must be a member of the Rotary Club. I call the woman who set up the speaking event and leave her a voicemail. “I’m so sorry,” I say, “but I won’t be able to speak at your event after all. Something’s come up.” Logically I know I can’t go back to jail now that I’m off probation, but this message about my past triggers me. This hatred from the community triggers me. For every two steps forward, I take one step back. Or maybe it’s the other way around. The only difference now is I don’t have to walk alone. I have Bryan Stevenson and Ray Hinton and Eileen and Doug. I have Sam and my children. I have my comedy friends. They love me, they trust me, and I try to tell myself that it’s enough to keep me safe. 
 chapter 21 REAL POWER I’ve had lots of imaginary conversations with Oprah Winfrey. I used to watch her talk show every afternoon. I laughed when she laughed, cried when she cried, and imagined myself sitting on a couch with her. Reading was escape, and so was Oprah. Ray and I are at Book Passage in Corte Madera, California. I’ve come to see him while he is on his book tour. The moms whose game night I couldn’t join at Kate’s house before I met the Dalai Lama have now invited me to join their book club. I gave them all my advance reader copies, the early versions of the book reserved for reviewers, and they’re also in the audience here, clutching their early copies. The bookstore’s owner is distressed at seeing the review copies in their hands. “You’re not supposed to have those,” she says to them. I step in and point to my name on the cover under Ray’s. “It’s okay,” I say. “Those are my copies, and these folks will still buy the hardback version tonight.” Dylan and Eileen are also with me, and it feels like a great event. Ray is on fire as he shares his story, and there’s not a dry eye in the house. After the event, we only have a little time to catch up before he’s whisked off to another event in a different city. I am in the office the next day when Ray calls. “Hellooooo,” I say. “That was such a great event last…” “Lara!” He’s whispering. “What?” I ask. “Are you okay?” He clears his throat. “I’m hiding in the bathroom at my hotel. Oprah Winfrey just called me. She told me it was Oprah, and at first I didn’t believe her.” “Really?” I ask dubiously. Ray is doing so well with his interview that they keep him on for an extra segment. He comes back to the greenroom and we hug, and I tell him he absolutely killed it. Before he can reply, Gayle and Oprah walk in. Ray introduces me to Oprah.
